From the opening scene to the thrilling conclusion, "The Dark Knight" directed by Christopher Nolan is a cinematic masterpiece that leaves audiences in awe. This film is a breathtaking and dark exploration of the battle between good and evil, with a level of depth and complexity that elevates it above your typical superhero movie.

At the heart of the film is the legendary performance of Heath Ledger as the Joker. Ledger's portrayal of the iconic villain is nothing short of mesmerizing. He brings an unparalleled level of intensity and unpredictability to the character, creating a Joker that is both terrifying and captivating. His performance is haunting, leaving an indelible mark on the history of cinema and earning him a posthumous Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor.

Christian Bale reprises his role as Bruce Wayne/Batman, delivering a riveting performance as the tortured and conflicted hero. Bale brings a depth and complexity to the character, showcasing Batman's inner struggles, moral dilemmas, and unwavering determination to protect Gotham City. His physicality and emotional range are on full display, making Batman a multi-dimensional and relatable protagonist.

The supporting cast is equally outstanding. Gary Oldman as Commissioner Gordon is the moral compass of the film, displaying unwavering integrity and determination in the face of chaos. Aaron Eckhart as Harvey Dent/Two-Face is brilliant in his transformation from a heroic district attorney to a vengeful and tragic villain. Michael Caine as Alfred provides a heartfelt and wise portrayal of Batman's loyal confidante, while Morgan Freeman as Lucius Fox brings his signature charm and intelligence to the role.

Nolan's direction is masterful, creating a visually stunning and emotionally resonant film. The action sequences are pulse-pounding and meticulously choreographed, leaving audiences on the edge of their seats. The film's dark and gritty tone is complemented by Hans Zimmer's haunting score, which adds another layer of depth to the film's atmosphere.

What sets "The Dark Knight" apart is its exploration of complex themes and moral dilemmas. The film delves into the nature of heroism, the consequences of vigilantism, the duality of human nature, and the blurred lines between right and wrong. It challenges conventional superhero tropes and presents a thought-provoking narrative that lingers long after the credits roll.

"The Dark Knight" is not just a superhero film, but a cinematic experience that transcends the genre. It's a thought-provoking, emotionally resonant, and visually stunning masterpiece that sets a new standard for superhero movies. Christopher Nolan's visionary storytelling, Heath Ledger's unforgettable performance, and the film's thought-provoking themes combine to create an epic masterpiece that will be remembered as a timeless classic in the history of cinema. Don't miss the chance to witness this extraordinary film on the big screen - it's an unforgettable ride that will leave you breathless.

Elevated immensely by the powerhouse that was Heath Ledger, The Dark Knight is bold, exciting, and unforgettable, making a claim for the greatest superhero movie of our generation. While its runtime is formidable for the genre, there isn't any fat on this film, instead filling its two and a half hour time with an intriguing and well-crafted story that adds depth to characters that are already admirably acted. Christian Bale, Michael Caine, Aaron Eckhart, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Morgan Freeman, Gary Oldman, Cillian Murphy, Nestor Carbonell, and somehow the list goes on. It's an impressive array of talent, especially given the superhero element, but director Christopher Nolan is always able to pull actors of this caliber due to his own prowess and, like his other projects, it elevates his final product immensely. At its core, The Dark Knight is a compelling and incredibly watchable action film, but it has interesting points to be made about how we perceive heroes and villains as bystanders. While the film doesn't delve too deeply into this element, it is always present and ramps up as the film concludes. It might have been nice to see some more of that introspection, but there was too little time on the clock when the crime drama is this good. Following the events of Batman Begins, The Dark Knight sees DA Harvey Dent (Eckhart) finally begin to clean up the mean streets of Gotham. When a mob accountant with damaging information is caught up in the city's cleaning effort, the criminal underbelly of Gotham turns to the mysterious Joker (Ledger) to eliminate him. What results is a thrilling chase through Gotham as Batman (Bale) is forced to play The Joker's game in order to save the city. The plot is so well-paced and engaging that it's easy to forget that The Dark Knight is a superhero movie at times. The set pieces are stunning and the action is so chockfull and well choreographed that I thought I was watching the concluding scene at only the 90-minute mark. In reality the film was just barely halfway done, a realization that was, itself, incredibly exciting at the time. Overall The Dark Knight is an exhilarating ride that makes excellent use of its runtime by filling the screen with tremendous performances and epic, unforgettable scenes. It holds up nicely after fifteen years and is likely still the best superhero movie of our time.

Chris Nolan's follow up to the excellent Batman Begins takes Batman and comic book movies to the next level of cinema with The Dark Knight. With this film Nolan has created arguably a masterpiece. The movie catches up with Batman (played fine by Christian Bale) in what looks to be not to long after Batman Begins. The film which nails everything. The film which turned the genre on its head and delivered an epic crime thriller. The film which redefined the era and left a lasting impact on not just the genre, but the industry itself. There's nothing else I could add to the conversation, but I'm going to try.

Christopher Nolan's "The Dark Knight" transcends cinema of its era. Somehow building upon the success of the great reset that was "Batman Begins", it also manages to stand on its own as the pinnacle of film in its era. 

It's not simply the Caped Crusader against his greatest foe, it presents them as mirror images of each other, putting the hero in a moral dilemma as he tries to save his city from further descent into chaos. This is elevated by perfect casting and performances. Cristian Bale builds upon his performance in the predecessor, both as Bruce Wayne and his crime-fighting alter ego. He delivers with passion, charm and likeability. Gary Oldman as Jim Gordon is even better and shows it in his shared sense for what is good with Bruce. Michael Caine continued to prove he was the ideal Alfred, with his foster father relationship with our protagonist. Maggie Gyllenhaal replaced Katie Holmes as Rachel Dawes, and is solid in the role. Lucius Fox is played well by Morgan Freeman. Aaron Eckhart gives a career best performance as Gotham's White Knight, Harvey Dent who later becomes Two-Face, embodying the theme of moral duality. The late, great Heath Ledger gives one the best performances of all-time as Gotham's prince of crime, The Joker. He serves as a mirror image of Batman, seeking to plummet Gotham to its inevitable fate, taking down the hero in the process. He doesn't need to kill him, just to go against his own moral code, believing everyone is corruptible, even Gotham's symbol of justice.

The score by Hans Zimmer & James Newton Howard also helps to engross the viewer into the experience. The visuals are also pretty clean, most of the action scenes executed with practical effects using minimal CGI. To think they actually blew up a factory!


The writing is also on point. As I alluded to earlier, the Nolans penned a compelling story which touches on duality, Batman as the titular character seeks to be replaced by a "White Knight", a conspicuous embodiment of hope and change. Joker wants to plunge the city into chaos. Harvey Dent and later Two-Face becomes the symbol of this duality. Order and chaos is the duality. This is what Joker seeks to unleash upon the citizens of Gotham. "Take away human beings' physical comforts and safety, they will turn into animals." All of his acts are calculated and are done to prove a point. Dent is a symbol of order by idealism, something for people to believe in, a "White Knight". Batman is presented as symbol of a necessary, invisible constant to ensure order is maintained, that nobody sees, a "Dark Knight". I have to give props for introducing us to the world of these films in the first film and then hitting us with this film second. The plot and character developments in these films are excellent.

Overall, "The Dark Knight" is a film which is very dear to me. It's a film I never get bored or tired of watching or talking about. A film which never ceases to entertain or surprise me. It took its premise and world seriously, using a fictional world to share real world truths which resonate with us. It stands toe-to-toe with not only the best sequels or comic book films but the best films of all-time, period. I can't think of anything I don't love about it. I'm genuinely in awe of this film.

Christopher Nolan's grim and dazzling sequel to his 2005 franchise reboot 'Batman Begins' is terrific entertainment. He brings us a hyper-realistic superhero movie with film noir shadings, getting at the roots of the Batman legend. His cerebral spin on the Caped Crusader raises the bar on comic-book movies and cinematic summer spectacles. This is considerably better than 'Begins'. The fights are more coherent, the drama more gripping and effecting, and the scope more epic. The cast is an embarrassment of great actors--Christian Bale is superb, Aaron Eckhart is charismatic and savage, Maggie Gyllenhaal shows why Katie Holmes was miscast in the first film, Gary Oldman is splendidly empathetic, Michael Caine and Morgan Freeman prove how they earned their Oscars. Pros like Eric Roberts, Anthony Michael Hall, and William Fitchner do service to chewy bit parts. But Heath Ledger reminds us of that old Hitchcock saying "Good villains make good movies." And The Joker, as envisioned by director Nolan and brother Jonathan (they co-wrote it together) and brought to vivid life by Ledger's psychotic, meticulous, delicious performance, is a GREAT villain. He's one of the most memorable bad guys of the decade, a genuine mystery of a sadistic madman. Ledger received a posthumous Oscar for his work here, and rightly so. This genius turn will live on in movie-going memory for years to come. The film is also a triumph of style, mounted with a superior technical quality. Wally Pfister's cinematography emphasizes the shadows, the harsh sunlight, and the eeriness of the night. His use of IMAX cameras for big action sequences is brilliantly thrilling. The editing is crisp (if choppy at brief moments), the effects and stunts are awesome, and the script gives us human characters we come to care about. Nolan's Batman story gets at the essence of film noir, which is there are no more heroes. By the end of this adventure the moral foundation of the Batman mythology has been thoroughly shaken, and we are compelled to see where Nolan and Bale take this character next. But for now we have arguably the best superhero/comic-book movie ever made, and one of the best films of 2008

The Dark Knight is Nolan's sequel to the acclaimed Batman Begins, and it not only met expectations, it far exceeded them. Possibly the best comic book superhero movie ever, TDK is gritty, violent, emotional, witty, heartbreaking, and thrilling. Christian Bale does a great job in the title role, but the show-stealer was Heath Ledger's Joker, which won a posthumous Oscar. Creepy and sadistic, Ledger brings the character to life in such a lively and convincing way that Ledger is well worthy of the awards he has won. Aaron Ekhart also knocks it out of the park as Harvey Dent/Two Face, and returning characters like Michale Cain's Alfred and Gary Oldman's Gordon liven the story. The plot is complex, exciting, and perfectly crafted. The characters are well-written, and it delivers some of the best scenes and stunts in movie history. And while plot conveniences abound, and some of the characters stray far from their comic-book origins, The Dark Knight is the definitive Batman movie.

Easily the best superhero movie to date, "The Dark Knight" sees Christopher Nolan at his absolute peak, providing a grounded and well told story that drifts from the childish aspects that the genre is known for and gives a much more serious and mature film that still tells a great story. The story was tightly crafted, with no detail going unnoticed, is packed with several emotional punches throughout due to its willingness to take risks. The actors did fantastically in their roles, most notably Ledger as the Joker, though I felt everyone had their time to shine no matter how insignificant their character might have felt. The score is fitting and tense, and the action sequences are used sparingly but are done to the absolute fullest. The props and stunts were also fantastically done, and I think Nolan really shows his unique directing style in this film. The final message of the movie was though-provoking, and the entire film feels grounded and realistic. Overall, a phenomenal piece of art in otherwise stale and copy-pasted superhero genre. A must-watch at least once.

Classic, and unbeatable material from a film that it's creators described as a film that wasn't going to feel first-and-foremost like an exercise in setpieces and fake CGI explosions and fantasy powers for genre fans. Bruce Wayne's backstory was fully explored in the previous set-up piece "Batman Begins", so no "personal low-point" cliché scenes appear before the Hero finally Saves the Day - even the morality of saving the day becomes somewhat ambiguous in this well cast film. My only criticism is it's edited slightly too fast.

Gotham City's crime is kept under control by billionaire-by-day, cape crusader, Bruce Wayne. As a masked vigilante, he is well feared and respected. But when an aimless villain known as the Joker begins to terrorize the town, Lieutenant Jim Gordon and District Attorney Harvey Dent assist Batman in capturing him. The team soon learns that every one of their choices are critical in turning them into heroes or villains.

With a cast as equally talented as it is star-studded, the film boasts a diversely elegant cast from the likes of acclaimed method actor, Christian Bale, to Hollywood veteran, Morgan Freeman.

The spine-chilling soundtrack complements the mystery and the darkness that constitutes the film's edginess.

The elaborate criminality, stunning visuals, effects, and explosions gave "The Dark Knight" a resonant neo-noir quality. 

The pacing is right on-target for a film that must deliver as much mystery as cutthroat action and adventure. Editor Lee Smith does an impeccable job of not letting the slower scenes feel like they're dragging, then sandwiching them in between scenes of thrill and breakneck action. I enjoyed that the wall-to-wall action was fueled by suspense. There were few cuts in massive stunt scenes which provided realism and authenticity to the violence.

Christian Bale as Gotham City's masked vigilante was dramatic, suave, stealthy, and well — dark! I admire that Batman steps back to question his own morals. He has to make decisions that nobody wants to make — heroic decisions that make it impossible to please everyone at the end of the day. Batman begins to realize that his role as the Caped Crusader of his villain-laden city could be one that is critical in good and bad ways. 

Heath Ledger's performance as Joker is brilliantly unmatched and befittingly abstruse, but that goes without saying. I love the fact that Joker's backstory here is constantly contradicted, giving his character an even more mysterious atmosphere. The audience understands clearly that this man just wants to watch the world burn and ask questions after. The fact that he has no apparent rhyme or reason builds anarchic suspense within the film and humor within the character.

Aaron Eckhart's Two-Face had a great backstory here. The parallels between fighting for justice with love and fighting justice for loss contribute to a profound plot twist. In Two-Faces case, he turned to evil. In Bruce Wayne's case, good was chosen. This made the slight rivalry between the two characters over Rachel Dawes (Maggie Gyllenhaal) that much more interesting, and solidified the two as perfect foes in the second act.

I thoroughly enjoyed "The Dark Knight" because it is unlike any superhero film around. By being so deep-rooted in the character's intentions and morals, we end up with what feels like a film about regular people who are taken to wild extremes by means of emotion and sacrifice. The stakes here are tremendously thrilling, full of adventure, meaningful and permanent. Great movie!

I'll be brief: yes, it's like everyone says. The second part of Christopher Nolan's Batman trilogy is a milestone for the superhero genre in many ways. Of course, over the years, voices have piled up that the film is overrated. A word that is used far too inflationary in the film world. And yes, presumably in times of modern superhero films by Marvel and co, The Dark Knight reveals many previously uncertain weaknesses. However, it remains to be said that the genre, which was not very popular at the time, opened up new dimensions for the box office.

With over just over one billion US dollars, the 2008 film was the first superhero flick ever to break through that barrier. Since then, there have often been several films of this genre every year that have managed to do so. Films that are nowhere near as revolutionary and significant. The Dark Knight has left its mark not only in terms of box-office takings. It did not introduce a new villain from the comics in the form of the Joker, who had already been seen in previous films. But it was written and portrayed in such a way that people are still talking about it 14 years later. Heath Ledger's breakthrough performance has been talked about enough. To disappear into a role is one thing. How Ledger manages to reinterpret this already established villain and have such an impact on the central plot is truly masterful. Many think that The Dark Knight is only hyped because of Ledger's performance. Sure, that aspect has a huge part to play, but alongside the anarchic troublemaker, we have another memorable character with the introduction of Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart). In several ways Batman's great rival, his development is both stirring and heartbreaking. For never would one initially believe that Dent's plotline would take such a course in the third act. The paeans to these two iconic figures almost make it seem as if our protagonist is more of a follower under the mask. But rather, Batman is the ideal complement to the crazed Joker, who is the exact opposite of the Caped Crusader. Anarchy meets justice - a combination that throws Gotham into an almost impossible-to-manage chaos. Well-established characters around Alfred, Lucius, Rachel and the new police chief Jim Gordon also get more depth and their special moments in the long running time.

But it is not only the brilliantly realised characters that make The Dark Knight the masterpiece of its genre. While Batman Begins very leisurely builds up the transformation of Bruce Wayne into Batman, this time Nolan delivers an action firework from second one. The film very rarely settles down and when it does, it knows how to focus on the element that interests us: The characters. This time around, Nolan leaves out the darkness that hovers around Gotham and doesn't really rely on settings. For over two and a half hours, we get to see an exchange of blows between good and evil - carried by a wonderful Hans Zimmer score.

Now that we are familiar with the back story and the character and our confidence in a Batman Franchise was restored Christopher Nolan surpassed all expectations by making a sequel that was gritty, action packed, and emotionally gripping.   It did not hurt that Heath Ledger gave a performance that exceeded all performances in any superhero film ever made-in fact it was a great performance by any standard.   Christian Bale continued to explore his inner conflict and to really take the audience along for a ride as we feel his pain and conflict over his role and place in the world.   Is he necessary? The 2008 Christopher Nolan film, The Dark Knight,  is a very skillfully developed cinematic masterpiece. The acting brings you right into the minds of the characters and at times makes you question their decisions while also making you understand why they believe what they do. The movie is motivated by relevant experience as we have all felt at an all time low and this is what drives the four main characters to their actions. Joker believes that the only thing fair in the world is anarchy so he chases that, Harvey Dent chooses to trust everything to chance, and Lt Gordan struggles with corruption in the police department. Batman struggles with all these things trying to protect the city while also maintaining his morals of not killing even when someone has caused so many deaths. The movie also brings into question dignity of the human person in a scene where the Joker places two bombs on two boats and puts a group of normal citizens on one and prisoners on the other. The citizens are arguing with each other about whether or not to blow up the other boat, and at one point someone says, " they are animals over there they have made their choices" this is not seen as a kind statement in the movie. Throughout the debate the question of the prisoner's dignity is pulled into question and ultimately the citizens decide that they are just as himan as they are. The attitude awareness is very negative as it explores what happens to humanity when it hits its lowest point. While the movie wasn't necessarily inspiring the whole time, near the end when Lt Gordon gives his monlouge to his son about what a hero is one can only feel inspired as Batman rides off into the darkness. Inspired by the sacrifice he makes so that the city might have a hero, even if it isn't him. While the movie does maintain a lot of violence and anger I think that it also exploresa lot of the philosophies that somehow make our world a hard place to live, it also sheds these in a negative light and shows the negative logic trails these ideologies can have when followed as embodied by the Joker and Two-face which i think give the movie balance

The Dark Knight Review
		The Dark Knight has a very unique script which enables you to be very engaged with the characters, it has lots of excitement with the action, and it enables you to reminisce about the previous film Batman Begins. The theme in The Dark Knight is power. In The Dark Knight Batman realizes that he's brought a great quantity of justice to Gotham, but he has more work to do once the Joker brings more corruption and destruction to Gotham. 
	 The Dark Knight makes us very invested in its characters through their power.   They see power in different ways. Bruce Wayne has power in an abundance of wealth. He uses it to help his friends such as when he uses it to help his friend Harvey Dent be voted district attorney of Gotham by throwing him a fundraiser.  He relies on science with his wealth to become Batman and with the help of Lucius Fox. Batman believes power is having the world be organized and controlling with rules. The Joker has power in which he's manipulative when he makes the police chief James Gordon not realize that he wants him to arrest him. The Joker also believes that power means having all the freedom you want with living in a world without rules or laws in, other words The Joker believes everyone should literally be able to do whatever they want. The film makes you want to be more invested with the characters after it ends. It makes you wonder if their meaning of power has even more to it after the film ends, or if their meaning is everlasting and there's no end to it.  
	The Dark Knight's action is exciting. One example would be when Lucius Fox Batman's technology expert guides him in a building where the Joker is causing mayhem, or another example would be when Batman shoots mines on windows and makes the windows explode. Batman driving his bat pod or bat motorcycle around Gotham is authentically exciting action.
	The Dark Knight has a unique and exciting script that creates plenty of nostalgia with enabling you to remember Batman Begins with many nods to it.

I'm not personally hugely into DC characters or movies that are made about those characters, but I think that The Dark Knight may be the best comic book film I've ever seen. This movie is dark, gloomy, unbelievably acted and brilliant in writing, direction and content. Christian Bale is by far the best Batman we've seen to date, and Aaron Eckhart and Heath Ledger give probably the best performances of their careers. From start to finish, Dark Knight is a thrilling crime movie that exemplifies the vigilante problem via the relationship that Batman has with Commissioner Gordon and the rest of Gotham's crime-fighting police squad, and it never lets you go. This is an anxiety building movie that keeps you constantly wondering and worried about what's going to happen next and how the movie is going to surprise you and subvert expectations. This is a Christopher Nolan movie that is smart and deep without getting too complicated and hard to follow the way some of his other films can be at times. Despite how much is going on in it, Dark Knight is a very refined movie with a clear focus and flows very smoothly despite how nerve-racking it is for both the characters and viewers. But the absolute highlight of this film is Heath Ledger's Joker. For a villain we've don't get a backstory for and know very little about in the movie, the Joker is a scary, complex, and intimidating villain who gives Wilson Fisk a run for his money. From the first time we see his face until his fate at the end of the movie, the Joker is a just as gripping as the movie is and is a villain who knows how to influence, mess with and terrify people. He is an antagonist who wants to fill people with fear and cause their society to do a 180 degree flip on itself and does so through very engaging and unique means you don't see coming and wouldn't think of to see in a comic book movie. Heath Ledger's performance, as I mentioned earlier, is mind-blowing; he is probably the best antagonist we've seen in any DC movie ever and I'm unsure if any villain could top him. This movie is dark enough and has complex enough themes that I'd even say this isn't a movie for kids; you need to be a little older and more mature to truly understand and appreciate what's going on in this movie. The Dark Knight is an absolutely must-see for DC fans and comic book fans in general as Marvel fans will find a lot to appreciate about this movie too.

The Dark Knight - 10/10. Christopher Nolan's legendary sequel to his genre changing reboot Batman Begins is literally the best example of how to continue on a story. The Dark Knight offers audiences the greatest comic book film that has ever been made. With riveting performances from Christian Bale, Anthony Eckhart, Maggie Gyllenhall, Michael Caine, Morgan Freeman, Gary Oldman, and of course, the Academy Award Winning performance of Heath Ledger, TDK dives you into the dark and cold world of Gotham. Nolan creates a Gotham that looks like its out of a page from Michael Mann's production notes. The city plays almost like a character to the dedicated vigilante of Batman. Unlike previous iterations, the Batman faces foes in this film that more than just evil. The Joker is literally a prankster anarchist, with no regards for whatever action they make. Two-Face is a fallen antihero who falls down the broken path as he loses the love of his life and also sees how corruption rots the city from within.  Then there are the gangsters who run amuck in the city, and this all is covered so expertly by Nolan throughout the film. The way he makes a superhero feel real, and also make it seem believable is astonishing. The Dark Knight was the first time watching a super hero movie where I felt, the explanations and the treatment made it real world. Its one of the reasons why it works so so well! And the political undertones and commentary are just perfect, commenting on real life situations and using the famous DC characters to showcase and explain the rights and wrongs of these thought processes. All in all, a legendary film that all should watch, regardless if you're a super hero film lover or not.

This film is considered to be one of the greatest superhero films ever made and very much for good reason. The Dark Knight strikes the perfect balance between an engaging superhero flick and a gripping crime thriller. Christopher Nolan's flawless direction beautifully complements Heath Ledger's enthralling performance, the Nolan brothers' screenplay, Hans Zimmer and James Newton Howard's scoring, and Wally Pfister's cinematography. Heath Ledger is stunningly believable as the Joker, landing dead center on the fine line between the Joker's dark hilariousness and utter psychopathy. Aaron Eckhart's portrayal of Harvey Dent is spot-on, as the extremely charismatic D.A. who becomes a psychopathic spree killer. The Dark Knight may just be my favorite superhero film, and mind you, I've seen quite a few superhero films.

I know it sounds a bit too cliché when someone says this, but this is undoubtedly one of, if not the best superhero movie ever created! It excels in every field it touches - The visual effects are done perfectly, the acting is absolutely Oscar worthy, the multiple storylines that don't seem too complex in spite of being told at the same time and in spite of being just one movie of a trilogy it managed to win the hearts of everyone who saw it.
The story picks up very well from where Batman Begins ended. The post credit scene in that movie had shown Joker, and I can very well imagine how excited the audience must have been seeing it. The Batman and Joker duo is used to describe the social aspects of the society, and explain how people might behave if they are left unhinged. A hero who has his moral codes and a lot to lose, compared to a villain without any moral codes and nothing to lose yet have so much in common than what meets the normal eye. Ultimately both are seen as freaks who must be eliminated by the law.
Let's talk about the characters, starting from Christian Bale's Batman. His voice sounds horrible as Batman. Nowadays many people have begun criticising it, but they don't realise that if a real Batman has to change his voice, he only has two ways of doing it - either using a voice modulator like Ben Affleck's Batman does, or deal with trying to sound different, which isn't easy when he has to breathe heavily because of how hard he works. It's just fun to see the caped crusader doing something on the screen.
Next let's address Michael Caine's Alfred. He's a good representation of Alfred. Just by looking at him you get the feeling of both a butler and a guardian, something we know Alfred to be. And it can be seen very nicely when he dresses Bruce's wounds or talks to him about his crimefighting.
Then we have Aaron Eckhart's Two Face. Unlike the previous iteration that was seen in Batman Forever, this one seems a lot more serious. He went through a hefty character development, from the patriotic white Knight of Gotham, Harvey Dent, to the deranged psychopath who is ready to cross all limits if he wants to have his revenge.
Jim Gordon is also a much, much better iteration from what we had seen in the 1989 Batman. He actually looks like someone who is invested in his job and can contact Batman whenever he needs help. He is the kind of Gordon I imagine when I think of the animated movies. When someone mentions Jim Gordon, this is the one who comes to my mind.
And finally the elephant in the room, the show stealer - Heath Ledger's Joker. Just like Two Face, Joker here has also gone through a complete makeover from what he was portrayed as in the previous movie that came in 1989. It's kinda sad that Heath Ledger never got to know how famous he has become, but his legacy shall forever live in the DC universe.
The Dark Knight is one movie I often come back to just to remember these kinds of superhero movies are also possible. Every DC character should be given such movies where their character is shown to develop as time moves on. This fire should not die out.

When I watched the Dark Knight for the first time I was enamored by everything the movie had to offer. From the stellar performances to the excellent writing, everything was created with careful planning and execution. So that's why I want to start the review by saying that this movie is a GOOD movie. I just so happen to not like it as much anymore.

*Spoilers*

This movie thrives on confusing and surprising the audience with every chance it gets, which is in my opinion this movie's greatest strength, unpredictability. Just think about it, Heath Ledger as the Joker is the perfect villain because when you look at him, you believe that he is an "Agent of Chaos" as he claims himself to be. And the definition for chaos is "behavior so unpredictable as to appear at random." So, I will dissect the first scene quickly so I can show you how Christopher Nolan uses unpredictability to his advantage. 

The scene opens up with five men going to rob a bank, two entering the bank from the roof, while three enter from the ground level. They all have their own job to do and like the men entering on the ground level say, this heist was really well planned. They mention in a brief conversation that they were hired by a clown who calls himself the Joker, who wears make-up like war paint to scare people. One guy on the roof called Dopey disables the bank's silent alarm while the other guy named Happy kills him as soon as the alarm is disabled. Surprise!

This is the first surprise to happen within this scene as the audience was not expecting the hitman to kill their teammates for a larger share. But the audience doesn't have time to react because as soon as the gun fires the movie cuts back to the ground level as they take hostages. A small detail to note is that instead of just tying the hostages up as a regular person would, the hitmen made them hold live grenades instead. Then one of the hitmen gets gunned down by the bank manager. And if you're surprised why the bank manager has a gun, well it's because this bank is owned by the mob! Surprise!

After subduing the bank manager, the Happy is shown working on opening the bank vault, while a guy from the ground level named Grumpy, prepares to get the money from the vault. As soon as the vault opens, Happy is killed by Grumpy who goes to collect the money. After Grumpy brings the money up so they can make their getaway, he gets run over by the bus driver as he backs through the front door. Surprise!

The last hitman kills the bus driver, making him the last hitman in the Joker's crew. When the bank manager starts talking to the final hitman about how the Joker will kill him too and calling him a fool, the hitman takes off his clown mask. As soon as you see the caked-on make-up, the excessive eye shadow around his eyes, and his messy green hair, you make the connection that this is the Joker. The Joker had successfully killed his entire crew so he didn't have to share any of the money at all. Then the Joker decides to leave a bomb in the manager's mouth so he'll stop talking. As the bus drives away, you expect the bomb to blow up but the bomb starts spraying a puff of smoke instead. Surprise!

So, I'm just going to say that if you watched this blind, there is absolutely no way that you would be able to predict what will happen next. I was expecting just a regular bank heist but as soon as the hitman started killing their teammates for a larger share, I didn't know what to expect from that point on. And this sequence is so quickly edited that it doesn't give you a lot of time to process what is happening until the end of the heist. This scene also did a good job of foreshadowing the Joker's character while also giving him one of the best character introductions I've seen to this day. The reason it works so well is that the audience has no idea what's going on, so it engages them with the mystery. 

So this movie already delivered one of the most unpredictable sequences in cinema history and it's only the first scene. I must say now that I've watched the movie three separate times in the past few years, that this scene does not disappoint even if you already know what the twists are. And that's a sign of good writing. 

Among the other things that I liked a lot about the movie were the actor's performances and how the movie wrote their characters. The highlights in this movie were Heath Ledger as the Joker and Aaron Eckhart as Harvey Dent/Two-Face. These two actors are so good at their job that their performances are never dull for a moment. These actors did lots of work to make their performances great, and with a script like this as your source material, they had loads to work with.

First, let's talk about the Joker. Everyone says that Heath Ledger's Joker is the best live-action Joker ever made, and I agree 100% with that statement. My favorite thing about the Joker in this movie is how he moves and how he demands that you pay attention to him. His reaction to the hospital not blowing up as he expected it to, is always hilarious to me as he looks genuinely disappointed in the outcome of the explosion. Then he is scared by the massive explosion a few seconds later. Also whenever he uses his hands when he makes a gesture or holds a knife to someone's mouth, I am at the edge of my seat watching and waiting for whatever he'll do next. Will he cut Rachel's mouth open, will he let Harvey shoot him in the face? So many questions.

And it's not just his movement that is captivating, the way he looks, the way he talks, all of it works to create this horrific villain that we have yet to see on the big screen like this. His messy green hair and his caked-on makeup make him look like a clown, but severely deranged. Although I don't know how to go about describing his voice, I can say that his laugh is what you would expect a maniac to laugh like. 

The story helps Ledger's performance a lot because this story gives him lots of opportunities to show off his acting skills. Like the scene where he is questioning a fake batman named Brian Douglas, the fact that he is holding the camera himself gives him a lot of creative liberty that allows him for a moment to take complete control over the cinematography. This just shows the massive respect Ledger and Nolan has for each other. The Joker also has many monologues within this movie where he can show his craziness on full display, especially whenever he tells the story of how he got the scars in his mouth. Plus he even gave these monologues while he was upside down. Now while Ledger's performance might be the best in the movie, my favorite performance is reserved for Aaron Eckhart who plays Harvey Dent/ Two-Face.

But first I need to go over the character arc of Harvey Dent. Harvey Dent's character arc is going from Gotham's "White Knight" to a man who has gone mad with revenge. Dent is a guy who believes in justice first and foremost, as he believes anyone that does something he deems would be immoral, should pay. When he is simply a District Attorney, his sense of justice is simple enough, "If somebody breaks a law, then that person has to pay for it." Whether it is a lifetime in prison or to pay a small fine, he believes whatever punishment the jury and the judge give that person, is fair. 

Dent believed in the legal system very much, so he found a way to let the Gotham Police Force arrest 549 men (who were in the mob btw) by prosecuting Lau under the RICO law. The mob, now under extreme pressure of becoming broke, hires the Joker to help them escape the arrest warrants and to get their money back. This starts the Joker's entire plan, which eventually leads to the Joker kidnapping Dent and Rachel Dawes (played by Maggie Gyllenhall), and giving them both a 50/50 chance of being rescued. Only one of them could be rescued though, and to Dent's dismay, he was rescued and Rachel died.

As Dent is sitting in his hospital bed, refusing medication and skin grafts for his facial injury, I believe he is blaming everyone who had a part to play in Rachel's death. Maroni's men, the Joker, Gordon, and even himself, he won't forgive any of them and wants to bring everyone responsible to justice. Even when Gordon apologizes, Dent doesn't change his mind.
When Dent sees the Joker while he is in bed, he is filled with rage to kill the man that he deems is truly responsible for Rachel's death. But the Joker lets him out on the secret that he never planned any of this to happen. In fact, that this was a spontaneous decision to create chaos, and that Dent should blame those who hired him. The reason I believe that the Joker is given a chance to live is that he is giving Dent the choice to introduce chaos in two ways, 1. Dent kills the Joker and everyone else goes off free and 2. Joker goes free and Dent kills the people who killed Rachel. 

This is a good time to decipher the symbol of the coin in this movie. The coin has two sides and if you flip the coin you have a 50% chance of getting heads or tails. Dent has a coin that has two heads that he flips to give people the illusion that he is leaving things up to chance when in reality, he isn't. Maybe you could say that since the only probability is 
"heads" 100% of the time, it isn't fair. He gave that coin to Rachel, and when she died one of those heads became blackened by the explosion that killed Rachel.

Since the coin now has a 50% chance to be heads or what I'll call tails for simplicity, he decides from here on out to give everyone who killed Rachel be given a 50/50 chance like she did that night starting with the Joker, who is set free. This brings us right back to Dent's ideals about justice which have changed drastically. He will no longer wait for a judge to decide the punishment for criminals because their punishment will never be fair. His view on justice is best described by his own words.

"The only morality in a cruel world is chance. Unbiased. Unprejudiced. Fair."

So why is Aaron Eckhart my favorite actor in this entire movie? Because if he couldn't accurately show Dent's fall from grace in a painful and dramatic performance, then I don't think this movie could've worked as well as it did. To me, Harvey Dent is the main character of this story and Aaron Eckhart is the main reason I enjoy the movie when I watch it again. Of course, it is still nice to see Heath Ledger as the Joker but it is the truth.

Eckhart had to play two characters in one movie and accurately depict what emotion he is feeling at every moment. When Dent allowed Gotham to arrest 549 criminals, at that moment he would feel proud and confident. Eckhart shows this confidence in the way he talks, the way he walks, even in his dialogue. "The mob doesn't scare me." He says this when the Joker threatens Dent and two others.

Something that I want to point out, is that every time Eckhart says the name "Rachel," it has some emotion attached to it to make it unique. When he talks to her normally, he talks nicely to be polite. When Rachel is about to die and he is being dragged from certain death, Dent wails Rachel's name over and over again until the explosion signals that she has died. Or when the Joker can't remember Rachel's name and Dent shouts Rachel's name angrily to remind the Joker of who he killed. This wide array of emotions is why I believe Eckhart to be the best actor in this film. 

Now I haven't even mentioned the actual main character of the story which is Bruce Wayne/Batman played by Christian Bale. And the reason I haven't mentioned him is that I find batman's character is kind of forgettable. I am not saying that Christian Bale's performance is bad but the script doesn't give anything for Bale to do other than do what the story needs him to do. The couple times the movie does stop to reflect on what Bruce Wayne is feeling after all these events, I feel like I hardly get any meaningful information out of those moments. 

Now compare Bruce Wayne's arc to Harvey Dent's arc. Both have lost the person that meant the most to them in their lives and Dent says "Why was it me who was the only one who lost everything?" to which Batman replies "It wasn't." Since the film devoted so much time fleshing out Dent's character and his romantic relationship with Rachel, him saying that he lost everything makes sense in this scene's context. However, when Batman is trying to suggest he lost everything too, it feels unearned because this movie hasn't given me a reason to believe that he has lost everything. I have been told by Bruce and Alfred that he has lost everything, but I haven't been shown a good memorable moment where I believed that Bruce truly lost everything in this movie. So sorry, but Batman was forgettable in his own movie.

I still don't think I can effectively critique cinematography and editing, and what makes good shots or good edits, but I can say that from a writing and acting standpoint this movie is solid, but I still have my problems with it.

This was an impressive sequel, though I had some issues with the pacing and plot. At times, this movie felt like it dragged, with a plot more convoluted and less contained than that of Batman Begins. I felt that much of it could have been condensed or omitted while retaining similar twists, suspense, and thematic discussions. Highlights of this film included the cast; Freeman, Oldman and Caine were excellent while Heath Ledger (R.I.P.) was simply brilliant as the Joker. Meanwhile, Rachel, the only woman in Gotham City, has been recast. I don't blame Katie Holmes for not reprising her role here, because in this film Rachel has been reduced even further from her two dimensional role as childhood-sweetheart-and-unattainable-love-interest into a caricature of a simpering, simple, damsel in distress. I found her portrayal in this movie to be almost unwatchable, and I felt absolutely nothing when she died. This was a massive waste of a character and undermined the emotional impact of the story. Meanwhile, the one Black man in this film outside of Morgan Freeman served one purpose: to look scary and intimidating in order to pull of a surprise message. A message which, by the way, felt weirdly out of place within the plot. Overall, this sequel is a strong continuation of the series and manages to explore a number of mature and serious themes, however, it could have done so with more cohesion and more emotion.

When somebody rates a movie as a 'must-see', there are two things which the movie may have accomplished: a) when watching the movie, there is literally not a single negative thing about the movie. And b) the movie affects or represents our culture to an extreme degree. The Dark Knight accomplishes both of these things in 2.5 hours. It is, without a doubt, one of the best films ever made. From the beginning, we are put into the angle of a villain who represents the opposite of Batman. Bruce Wayne, aka Batman, represents order, steadiness, and morality. The Joker represents the polar opposite: chaos, destabilization, and the belief that everybody is morally corruptible. The biggest feat of this movie is that the villain is correct. Every single person is capable of evil, and that's the underlying message of this film. Harvey Dent represents everything good about Gotham. He has hope and strong moral values. But the Joker is at work in him, slowly eating away at the underside of Gotham like acid. And when the Joker picks Harvey Dent, all falls to chaos. It is difficult to describe how deep the relationships between all of the characters are. From the opening bank robbery scene, to the Joker's epic conclusion, to Two Face's violent crimes, the hate of the characters in this movie can practically be felt through the screen. The Joker is physically greater than Batman; he is not stronger, but impossible to physically and mentally break. Batman's pathetic attempts against him are feeble against the underlying plan of the Joker. "Madness, as you know, is like gravity... all it takes is a little push."

Wow, The Dark Knight is one hell of a movie. Despite having a bumpy start, the Batman franchise got revolutionized by Burton's imaginative and dark vision and we got Batman 89. From this point, the Batman Universe relies on a dark brooding atmosphere, complex dialogue and story, amazing effects and eerie scores, instead of campy surf battles and Z grade qualtiy. The Dark Knight is no exception. The basic premise of Batman versus his arch nemesis Joker is elevated by a complex dark story in which Joker (masterfully played by Heath Ledger, his best performance to date, unfortunately he died after the shootings ended and missed his Supporting Actor Academy Award) is to terrorize and wreak havoc in Gotham City.  Anyways, Batman (played by method actor Christian Bale, truly iconic) and Chief Gordon team up and try to stop Joker's evil plan. However, Joker always seems to be a step further, which makes the mission harder than expected. We see that instead of a non descript Joker who does want to control the city just because he has to be the villain (Yes we are taking about you Cesar Romero, couldn't even shave his own moustache for the role), we have a very anarchic Joker. An ambiguous one, whose backstory variations contradict one another and his goals are beyond our understanding. Beyond sanity and logic. He tortures people just for the fun of it and burns currency just for the hell of it. He is a plethora of emotions and characters into one, quite possibly Alex from A Clockwork Orange and Jack Nicholson's Joker. That is what makes him an effective and menacing villain in this movie. We also cannot forget Chrstopher Nolan's tense, fast paced direction, which makes every scene gripping and breathtaking and the technical achievements on tis one, particularly the cinematography, the sound, the makeup and the visuals. Topping all of that with Hans Zimmer's signature minimalistic score and an amazing opening sequence, I must say that The Dark Knight is a revolutionary and gripping film that anyone, even those who despise superhero movies, will have to watch because of its being a versatile film. It manages to be an action, thriller, drama, mystery and a Superhero film altoghether. The half a star I cut will be for the whole Hong Kong sequence which I found superfluous and literally didn't affect the plot in any sort of way.

The Dark Knight (2008) is not only the perfect follow up to Batman Begins (2005), but it is also perhaps the perfect comic book movie. Christopher Nolan's grounded super hero franchise allows for a realistic and intriguing story, helmed by not only a great villain, but also an Oscar-awarded performance from Heath Ledger. The way the Joker was crafted with his insanity, his motives made sense, how he just wanted to chaos and destruction. 

The story benefits from appearances of Bruce Wayne and the Joker, however whenever there are scenes without them, you don't notice their absence as it is very easy to get caught up in the amount of layers and detail put into this political plot. Those scenes without Bruce and the Joker mainly being those with Harvey Dent, who's arc throughout this film is executed perfectly.

Comic book movies are often not considered for the Oscars, but The Dark Knight (2008) has been one exception, and rightfully so. The films grounded and realistic world lends itself perfectly to a Batman story, combining that with a fantastic story and a legendary final performance from the late Heath Ledger, you have one of the best comic book movies of all time, as well as one of the best movies of all time.

Batman has created a sense of fear among Gothams criminals and with the rising influence of the new District Attorney Harvey Dent the decrease in crime is evident, that is until the Joker begins a rain of terror never before seen by Gotham.

This is one of my favourite movies ever made, Nolan's ability to take this classic character and create something that is not only a wild ride but an incredibly well written film is unbelievable.

Heath Ledger as the Joker is the greatest movie villain ever, not just comic book movies, movies in general. To begin with the character is flawlessly written, Jokers goal is essentially to fix society. The Joker throughout the entire film showcases what is wrong with society and forces people to make these extremely difficult decisions that challenge their morals. When you take that writing and pair it with the phenomenally psychotic performance given by Heath Ledger you get one of the greatest characters in cinematic history.

Christian Bale of course returns as Batman and does an amazing job once again. The Joker forces Bruce to make certain decisions about what Gotham needs versus what is right and it really challenges Bruce. It makes him question his morals and question whether or not what he is doing is inspiring good or creating more evil.

Aaron Eckhart is extremely underrated as Harvey Dent. His character is basically Batman as a District Attorney, they have the same goals but achieve them in different ways. But when he loses Rachel (Maggie Gyllenhaal) his response is much different from Bruce's. Dent loses faith in society and with a little push from Joker he becomes Two-Face and shows what can happen when society pushes someone over the edge.

This movie is perfect in every way and I can not thank Christopher Nolan enough for another phenomenal film.

The Dark Knight was a defining moment in Christopher Nolan's career. What I admire in Nolan is that he seems to find the perfect balance between thrilling blockbuster and a rich and full story, The Dark Knight is one of the best examples of this. The overall direction and writing of this film makes Batman, who, before these movies was still the campy 60s Batman to a lot of the public, the dark and gritty character we're so used to today. Batman, as a character, is absolutely timeless, and Nolan recognizes this, making the topics in his movies timeless as well. We have all felt chaos in our lives, and the Joker is a great representation of that, which, compared to Christian Bale's Batman symbolic as a man focused on justice, is an excellent contrast. While Christian Bale is fine as Batman, I did prefer his performance in Batman Begins. The performance that really makes this movie work is obviously Heath Ledger as the Joker. The way he manages to capture that character in such a menacing way is admirable. It's a shame that he won't be able to play the Joker again, because the simply way that he spoke is immediately recognizable. My biggest complaint would be the look of the film. I understand what Nolan was going for, but aesthetically, a lot of this film was extremely dark. It would have been nice to see Batman against a grey sky at some point. I also found that the two-face story line was extremely rushed, and should have been fleshed out in its own movie, as the character is great. I just feel like it was an underused plot-line, the character should have been set up as two face near the end. That way, the Joker would still have an effect on the story, and the story would have been more fluid. I know a few people who prefer Batman Begins, saying that the story is a lot less forgettable, yet, while parts of this story are forgettable, the characters are much more fleshed out and the story is much more compelling. This movie marked a significant change in the superhero genre, and that's no easy feat.

The only thing that saves The Dark Knight from being completely terrible is Heath Ledger's performance as the Joker. He is fittingly fidgety and unpredictable, the perfect foil to Christian Bales's boring, noble, scratchy-voiced Batman. The lip licking, the sudden spurts of violence, the complete lack of fear of death or pain make Ledger's Joker a truly formidable villain. However, the rest of the movie falls far below the level of his performance. Morgan Freeman, Michael Caine, and Gary Oldman's characters are just as bland and uninteresting as they were in the original. The real sin the movie commits is that it pretends to be more than it is, a silly super hero movie, by adding supposed layers of philosophy and sociology and pretentious "intellectual" dialogue, and to me that's the most insulting thing a film can do. It's as if Christopher Nolan knows he can't give a Batman movie a weightier theme than hero-in-an-animal-themed-tight-suit-fights-bad-guy-with-a-crazy-plan-to-destroy-the-city, but tries anyway, in an attempt to justify to himself and his viewers why he's making yet another movie about the caped crusader. Even without all the artificial philosophy, the plot is nonsensical and it is entirely unenjoyable for the sole reason that it is played out so seriously. Unlike the 1966 Batman, which did the opposite, this movie attempts to pass every second of itself off as believable, realistic, and dark. The second villain in Aaron Eckhart's Two Face just tops it off when he defies the tremendous pain he must be in after having had half his head burned off by threatening monsters and kidnapping hostages. And the meant-to-be-realistic effect of his burned face looks sillier than purple makeup would have. The only reason it's been so well received is that it's purported depth makes superhero nerds feel like their favorite kind of movie has a place in great cinema.

Christopher Nolan's noir film The Dark Knight (2008) is a landmark of cinematic excellence. I remember being stunned in theaters when I first watched this phenomenal crime picture. I actually started to collect all the movie tickets after seeing The Dark Knight because this movie made me realize how important movies are to me.

Heath Ledger steals the show as a modern and malevolent incarnation of Batman's archnemesis The Joker. He is gleeful in his chaotic violence and careless anarchism that is truly frightening. Ledger is so remarkable as Joker that every single line he utters, mumbles, or giggles out in The Dark Knight is quotable and unforgettable. He is the definitive version of Joker to me surpassing Cesar Romero, Mark Hamill, Jack Nicholson, Jared Leto, or even Joaquin Phoenix. Ledger proves everyone that doubted his casting wrong as he is magnificent as Joker. I miss him so dearly. I wish he never died so that you could know how much we all loved him. Rest in paradise Heath Ledger.

Christian Bale is outstanding as the brave and dejected Bruce Wayne, while being fearsome and intimidating as Batman. His impressive physique, quiet manner, piercing expressions, and heartfelt emotional connection create a fully formed character out of this comic book hero. Bale was born to play Batman. Michael Caine returns as the dry witted English butler to Batman named Alfred Pennyworth. I love his monologue about hunting a bandit who, "just want to watch the world burn." Gary Oldman is courageous and kind as the likable Commissioner James Gordon.

Aaron Eckhart is glorious as the smug and confident Harvey Dent in all his just lawyering, while haunting and scary as Two-Face. 

I'm still not crazy about Maggie Gyllenhaal as Rachel Dawes. I still wish Katie Holmes had returned as her intelligent and sincere Rachel. She had such natural chemistry with Christian Bale. Gyllenhaal is still lovely and apt for the role of Rachel, but she plays her so differently. She is not as affectionate as Holmes was with Bale and seems more dedicated to Harvey than her work, so that you never think she'd end up with Bruce Wayne anymore. I think Maggie unfairly had a hard time after The Dark Knight came out and people insulted her looks because she is still excellent as Rachel and gets some serious dramatic moments I will not spoil.

Morgan Freeman is more conscious of his ethics and morals as the steadfast Lucius Fox. Chin Han is fun as Mr. Lau. Eric Roberts is excellent as usual as the crime boss Sal Maroni. Keith Szarabajka is excellent as the tough cop guarding Joker in the interrogation room called Gerard Stephens. William Fichtner is so awesome as the brave, if foolish, bank manager Joker robs in the killer cold open to The Dark Knight. He wields a shotgun like great gravitas and intent. I like Cillian Murphy's fun cameo as Scarecrow. Lastly, David Dastmalchian is truly amazing as the insane Thomas Schiff. His crazy face is so striking that you never forget him here.

The Dark Knight is intelligent, original, and masterful. Christopher Nolan's direction and writing are immortalized within this essential feature film. Nolan upped the ante after his sublime motion picture Batman Begins by bringing Joker to the silver screen once more after Jack Nicholson's incarnation in Tim Burton's Batman. Nolan's ambition and scale are impressive as he opens with a killer bank robbery, pulls off a shocking car chase, and converts Chicago into Gotham so that you always feel you're looking at a real place. The Dark Knight is a must see movie because it's 152 minutes of pure Batman lead action.

Christopher Nolan's direction is astounding. He finds every clever angle, twist, and new way to show Batman's old tricks. There's nothing more I can say about The Dark Knight that other critics and fans have not praised for over a decade now. Nolan went overboard with the engaging complex story about Batman facing decisions over whether or not to remain as Batman or retire with Rachel only to get pulled into a tumultuous conflict with Joker and Two-Face. Christopher and Jonathan Nolan's script is stuffed with funny jokes, shocking reveals, harrowing violence, and clever setups with thrilling payoffs.

Lee Smith's editing is sleek and polished so that you always know what's happening even as Smith cuts all over Gotham as several storylines will converge at once into a wave of crime for Batman to contend with simultaneously. Wally Pfister's cinematography is already iconic. Joker burning the pile of money, Batman running into the night, or Joker standing in the middle of the street screaming for Batman to hit him are legendary wide shots. The visual effects are amazing, especially for Two-Face's make-up and CGI.

Hans Zimmer and James Newton Howard's score for The Dark Knight is so memorable that you will never forget the excitement at hearing their Batman theme. Lindy Hemming and Patrick Caulfield designed iconic and striking purple and green suits for Joker to adorn. Their Batsuits are cool and modern just like Two-Face's half burnt suit. John Caglione Jr., Nancy Hancock, and Sue Robb-King deliver cinema's scariest make-up for Joker's garrish clown face.

Is The Dark Knight perfect? No, I cannot lie, but that does not detract from how magnificent a film it remains with enthralling action and heartbreaking drama that makes you think and feel. Not sure why after Batman catches Rachel from falling, he just leaves a room full of people at the fundraiser alone with Joker. I hate the line, "No more dead cops" as well as the police officer complaining while a helicopter flies towards him and he only slightly alarmed says, "That's not good." I can forgive that bad line and poor acting. It's also strange how the Batmobile jump cuts into the parking complex in the beginning from where it would have had to drive up the side to get its dramatic entrance. But, I can chalk that up to a strange edit and he's Batman so he can do whatever.

In all, The Dark Knight will persevere as one of the very best Batman movies as well as one of Christopher Nolan's greatest films. It still gets ranked up with the greatest films of all time everywhere and I cannot disagree. The Dark Knight is always an intense and entertaining watch.

The Dark Knight is immediately willing to throw out everything that worked in Begins, in favour of something bold and new. Expectations were shattered in every respect. It took leftfield but wholly appropriate influences such as Heat and the more interesting comics like Gotham Central, to craft something not influenced by previous comic book movies. And Nolan, trusted to be let loose, refined his style that is still, in many ways, his absolute peak.

The sound and sound mix quality is absolutely superb, right from the opening, there are some expansive layers and breadth to it. I mean it's maybe one of the best I've ever heard. And Zimmer's score here is the coursing lifeblood of the movie, the nerves and sinew. The intensity and fear and chaos. That's why I think it's unquestionably Zimmers best modern electronic score; it was fresh, it's necessary not distracting.

Dialogue crackles. Scenes whip by so fast that you sit up and pay attention. And this film would have rocketed along and been very good indeed as it starts out to be. But then the movie turns its up to eleven. And chaos turns up. The exact thing to disrupt this perfect political drama and turn it on its head. The joker. 

What to say that hasn't been said about The Joker?

He's the embodiment of Post-911 fear. The movie keeps wanting to tell us, don't give in to terrorists or to fear or they win. He's not crazy. And he's super smart and he's not a psychopath either. He's funny and he knows humour. That means something. That means he's capable of greater evil. His backstory is simultaneously a sort of fourth wall joke, the different versions something that only the Joker could know is a private joke, and yet is completely serious to him. His backstory is frightening and unknown, just the same way that the motives for terrorism were certainly, at the time, unknowable and serious and shifting.

The Dark Knight taught us that comic book movie adaptations didn't have to only rely on the previously set tones of their forefathers, it still is a beacon of comic adaptations future, teaching them to unshackle and find something real to say, without TDK, Wolverine simply wouldn't have known that it could have borrowed from Westerns to create Logan.
Two-Face is a great example of taking the origins of the character in the comics and twisting it to fir this world; the casting of perfect pretty-boy Eckhart, the way he gets his name from a past in IA which links to Gordon and even his hatred of Gordon, the bait and switch in the courtroom, all perfected when the ballerina places a menu in front of his face and it's clear how much of a White Knight he is and could be. It's elegant stuff really. And when his dark side kicks in he doesn't seem like an actor playing anger, there's a hitherto unseen rage inside Eckhart that bursts out in a deviousness and a genuine darkness.

In terms of plot, think of a better film that kills of the childhood sweetheart of the main hero and she wasn't super powered and didn't come back to life? These days they'd tear this choice away from the filmmakers on the basis of franchise longevity but here they went full-tilt.

The shifts in ratio from IMAX to 35mm and back again aren't jarring as they feel right in the edit - there's flow, a kind of intentional idea of how to cut inbetween almost seamlessly or certainly artfully, it's really a pleasure even if you focus on it. This is unlike absolute clusterfucks like Transformer's ironically titled: The Last Knight. 

It's got flaws: An act too many, even though it's brisk and well made. And things like the Jokers contrived plan to get caught, which was all the rage at the time, is farfetched and plot-hole-inducing. Also I'm sure the way that he gets prints off of a bullet makes no sense. 

Nice little quirks are present here: The well cast Mr. Reese that can be read as a possible nod to The Riddler (Mysteries!). The Gotham Central connections stood out well, as did the moments taken from The Long Halloween. And that Batpod reveal still takes me by surprise no matter how much I've seen this movie, and like the first time has me fist-pumping and cheering and grinning from ear to ear. And there are many great filmmaking choices that I only registered upon watching this time, such as Alfred saying goodbye to Rachel who dies shortly after, giving her character a modicum of closure before we realise it. And that editing: The slam of the door on Harvey's face and more little moments that are almost laugh out loud in how damn cheeky they are. This is bravura actual honest-to-god filmmaking. 

And still there's more: The Joker's yellow teeth because of course he doesn't brush. That phone explosion seen more powerfully from far away. The epic truck/security van chase with no music that just bristles with 70's cop movie electricity. And how powerful a moment when a man who is saved can be screaming to wish he was dead because if he's alive then someone he loves will be dead in his place. Good stuff Nolan, you may now make whatever you want for the rest of your life.

It took a while but eventually I understood why this film is so terrible apart from the many gaping plot holes and ridiculous actions by characters - you know, the ones that make you shout at the screen. There are deeper problems that infest the superhero genre itself and are particularly egregious in The Dark Knight. Why is Gotham have so much crime? The script demands that we assume it's simply because there are some horrible individuals living there, exploiting others. But who are those people and why are they acting like that? 

Then we must ask: is it really only a wealthy, white man who can save Gotham from what is assumed to be a problem caused by individuals? What about the capitalist system on which Gotham runs, a system which has clearly enriched one family - the Waynes - but has failed to trickle down to the rest of the city's population? Is there no alternative, as the UK's right-wing politician Margaret Thatcher once claimed?

Ultimately, this film tells us that capitalism would be fine if only those annoying criminals who take its lessons about entrepreneurialism and wealth creation too seriously would stop breaking the law. And that white saviours are always the only solution to social problems - it's never about social solidarity, the people working together to take power back from those wealthy few who hoard it for themselves.

After watching The Dark Knight it really made me see what we are missing in super-hero movies these days.  Today most super-hero flicks rely on the same shtick and gimmicks, and they all feel as if they are not so much of a movie as a TV show that lasts for two hours, The Dark Knight reminded me of what a movie looks like. I am going to start this review by saying that this is my favourite movie of all time. Every single second of the two hour and thirty-two minute run time is amazing to watch; there is never a dull moment. I will start off by saying that this review will be spoiler free at first, but later on I will get into spoilers. I will warn you when that happens so be on the lookout. To start, let's talk about The Joker. Heath Ledger, rest in peace, is phenomenal as The Joker. This is, in my opinion, the best acting performance of all time. I do not see someone acting here. I see a terrifying villain who had footage recorded of him, and the footage was used for the movie. That is how good Heath Ledger is in this film. You also have Christian Bale as Bruce Wayne/Batman. He is spectacular as well. A lot of people say that the voice gets on their nerves, but I personally really enjoy it. It makes sense to me, seeing as he wants to keep his identity secret, that a voice like that would be used. Aaron Eckhart as Harvey Dent is also spectacular. Without spoilers, he is great early and later on in the movie. The writing of this movie is fantastic, as there are two different ideologies at work here. Batman has the rule that he cannot kill anyone, and The Joker wants chaos, he wants to prove that the people of Gotham are just like him. This creates a very exciting dynamic between the two characters that never goes away. I am now going to talk spoilers, so if you have not seen the movie, stop reading, and go watch the movie. The first thing I want to talk about here is the interrogation scene. This is some of the best dialogue in any movie I have ever seen. The Joker is toying with Batman, wasting his time so that he can ensure Batman will have to make a choice between to people; Rachel or Harvey. The Joker later switches the addresses so that no matter who Batman chose, he would kill the person he wanted to save. The cinematography in this scene is also fantastic. The camera starts with The Joker on one side and Batman on the other. As the scene goes on, the camera position changes, and the sides are switched almost seamlessly. This implies that Batman is crossing over to The Joker's side, that The Joker is winning. This is what I believe to be the best scene in the movie. Later on in the movie, Harvey Dent is in an accident and becomes Two-Face. This is where Aaron Eckhart really shines as Harvey. His character development makes complete sense, as he has been through a traumatic experience in  losing his fiancee, and The Joker manipulated him soon after. It is very heart breaking to see such a good man become so terrible, but you can really understand why this is happening. Now for the ending of the movie. Batman breaks his one rule at the end of the movie by killing Harvey Dent. Through fighting The Joker, he realized that sometimes he would need to break the rules for the greater good of everyone else. He realized that he was not a hero, he was something more. He was whatever Gotham needed him to be. That last part was taken from the movie, because it is just so powerful. Things echoed to Bruce earlier on in the film, things he does not believe at first, but by the end of the movie the character arch is complete, and he knows what he must do for the city of Gotham. The order in which we are shown the closing shots is important too. Because the last thing seen is Batman riding away, with Gordon explaining to his son about Batman being a watchful protector, it leaves a feeling of ambiguity; it feels like he could be back one day. If you have read through regardless of spoilers, watch it. If you have seen the movie before, watch it again. It is my favourite movie of all time, and even if it is not yours, it is still a fantastic movie.

Heath Ledger Joker, that's all I need to say about this movie and it is all this movie is, and it is heavenly. The Dark Knight is the sequel to Batman Begins and if that movie was any indication of how Nolan's series would go, you were wrong because this film exceeds every expectation and gives you more than you possibly could have ever dreamed of in a Batman movie. This film is contextually darker, but does not appear physically darker, this movie is a psychological battle for the most part and it works perfectly with the style and tone of the Joker in this movie. Speaking of the clown prince of crime, Heath Ledger completely reinvented villains because of his take on the Joker, he gave a once in a lifetime (Oscar-winning), outstanding performance. I mean, Ledger gave it his absolute all in this role and it payed off bigtime, he had a great voice for the Joker, and he had that dark and twisted humour that was necessary for success in his role, and he delivered. Lets not exclude the Batman here, Bale once again played his role perfectly, but he kind of takes a back seat to the Joker in this movie, and we get more of Bruce Wayne than we do of Batman, but nobody minds that too much because the Joker is the main attraction here, the movie knows that and it centers around his character giving us plenty of screen time. This movies script is amazing and it gives the Joker so many great lines, almost everything he says is instantly iconic and memorable. Gary Oldman and Aaron Eckhart both killed it in this movie, they both gave their best performances and they are really good as their characters. Oldman IS commissioner Gordon, he really sells his fantastic performance and he becomes Gordon, you really do forget that he's just an actor reciting lines from a script, he was just so good. Eckhart is very underrated in this movie, he is an excellent DA and political crime fighter and he does it with such poise and and charisma, he is also pretty good as Two-Face. This movie really got Harvey Dent right, they introduced him and showed us what he stands for and believes in, and the movie builds up his character greatly and then shows us his fall to Two-Face, it was a great character arc that is clearly visible and understandable. Michael Caine was once again great as Alfred. The other cast members include Morgan Freeman, Maggie Gyllenhaal, Nestor Carbonall, and William Fichtner who were all great as well. The Batpod in this movie is amazing, it looks and moves great and it is really cool, way better than the tumbler. This film is a cinematic masterpiece with a great story, great script, great score, great characters and character development, gorgeous cinematography, great practical effects, great tone, great themes, great performances, and it raised the bar for comic-book/superhero movies, that I doubt that it can ever be passed. This is one of my all time favorite films ever created, it is flawless and Christopher Nolan directed the hell out of this movie, he will be remembered as one of the greatest directors in cinematic history just because of this movie alone. I strongly recommend viewing this precious piece of art and basking in all of its glory right after Batman Begins, you will not be dissapointed.
