I remembered my experience of watching this film in the theaters with a group of people and for the life of me, cannot understand why we decided to sit up front as it left me with ringing ears and dry eyes. I remember experiencing this sense of amazement with each scene blowing me away as they pass by. Though back then, I was very ignorant of cinema and I only went to watch this for a good time. Coming out of the theater, I was so hooked onto the film that I didn't even realize that I was hearing this ringing in my ear due to the bombastic sound mix of the film. This film introduced me to the world of comic books and became very interested with the stories that surrounded this character. This film did make an impact on my mid-teenage years and introduced me to things that I never thought I would be interested in.

The Dark Knight's screenplay was written by Christopher and Jonathan Nolan with story contributions by David S. Goyer. The writers have written a spectacular film that touches on themes like justice, morality, trust, chaos and order. They have taken these themes and wrapped it around a battle between two individuals who are fighting for Gotham's soul, and I found this idea to be very interesting. It was finally exciting to see someone that can truly go up against with someone as strong and symbolic as Batman. The first film addresses the importance of Batman acting as a symbol for Gotham, to protect Wayne's loved ones and to create an idea that is indestructible, but the writers contradicted that here by conjuring up a similar being that nobody could understand and boasts polarizing values causing cracks in Batman's values and legend. This allowed the writers to have stakes for the protagonist to be much higher and eventually involving members of his personal life. Underneath the surface, lies a couple of sub plots that keep us interested between the big moments. One of these sub plots include the romance between Bruce Wayne and Rachel Dawes, which didn't feel forced and was only used in order to show the audience another shade of Wayne and an apparatus tool for the main plot. I was actually surprised on how they handled this romance, because action-oriented films tend to really force it in and it brings the film down. The film also carries the ideas from the first film about trust and corruption, indicating that Gotham is still being plagued by this and the people who are idealistic, particularly Jim Gordon and Harvey Dent, are finding it hard to create progress towards restoring the image of Gotham. The film's dialogue is definitely a step up from the previous film as it is much more well written, I think it had something to do with Jonathan Nolan being involved with the writing process, and it doesn't seem to be as pushy anymore in being clear with it's themes and messages. It is more concerned with driving the film along and creating tension, while still giving it a layer of depth that is present to be explored if one is interested to search for it.

The film was directed by Christopher Nolan who, by the film's release, has already proven to be a notable director but this was the film that made him the important director that everyone now claims him to be. Though I agree with this praise, I don't agree that this was his strongest film as I felt that his next two films were his masterpieces, at least that's how I feel about them for now. Nolan has created a film that proved that films within the comic-book genre can be serious and that it can stand against or with the greatest films of all time. There was issues I had with the first film that was fixed here and one of the main ones was the city itself. The first film treated the city as just a setting for the story to take place, though it did try to create the world through having important citizens be present on screen, it just wasn't enough. Nolan corrected this by having multiple characters who are not really that important be more involved with the film's plot, some of these include characters like Ramirez, Maroni, Mayor Garcia, Lau, Chechen, Reese, Commisioner Loeb and Mike Engel. Their involvement makes the world of Gotham more convincing and it allows the setting to become a character of it's own and show a sense of "character development". Nolan also made the decision of using more of locations during exterior scenes rather than use sound stages like Batman Begins; making the world look more convincing and natural. This was also the first time where Nolan has shown his ability to handle something so ambitious. He really made great use of the studio's budget and combining it with artistic license. Nolan has improved upon the action from the first film by making them bigger and ambitious. He also widened the scope of the film by having scenes be shot from different countries and backdrops. The action was not entirely original but they were great in creating tension and excitement from it's audience, particularly the warehouse sequence and the final showdown between Batman and Joker. I felt this film was well paced, definitely an improvement from the previous film, balancing excitement with storytelling. Nolan wants us to be completely invested on what is happening on screen. The film's editing wasn't as erratic as the first film, particularly with the action sequences. Nolan has managed to show most of the scene's choreography and still manage to create that feeling of tension and intensity that was necessary to sell the scene.

The film's director of photography was Wally Pfister, a common collaborator of Nolan. Pfister has changed the look of the franchise, giving the film a more natural look as compared to the first film that had a brown palette and a dirty look. I found this approach to be much more favorable as it didn't try so hard to be noticed. Pfister has placed all of his focus instead on the performance of the actors, the storytelling and creation of beautiful shots. As this film is a performance driven film, particularly for Heath Ledger, there was emphasis on capturing it and ensuring it retains that intensity until the scene is over. The film also contained beautiful helicopter shots and action sequences which were shot with IMAX cameras capturing wonderful detail and colors that 35mm probably couldn't achieve. It's too bad that I wasn't able to watch this in an IMAX theater as it would have probably blown my mind. Like Batman Begins, Pfister went back and forth with the erratic hand held approach, found mostly in action sequences, to the steady hand-held/mounted style used primarily in dialogue driven moments. It is much more controlled here with Pfister being more confident with his style of shooting. Pfister also allowed the choreography to be more in display which was essential in selling the action-oriented scenes.

The film's score was composed by James Newton Howard and Hans Zimmer. It still features the great epic score from the film's predecessor and combines it with a couple of new compositions that are just as epic as the main theme. Both composers were able to create tension through the heavy use of strings. They were able to create this sense of chaos and unpredictability with the score, particularly when the Joker is on screen; there is this presence of a screeching note symbolising the madness in this character. The composers were able to create this weight to the story with their score, making it feel like it's bigger than just an action comic-book film.

The acting in The Dark Knight is much better, than compared to Batman Begins. This may be due to better written characters and a story that demands more from the actors. Christian Bale was fantastic as Bruce Wayne. His performance here feels much more natural and more entertaining to watch. It's the moments between Bale, Eckhart, and Oldman that showcases the best of his performance. Heath Ledger was definitely the gem in the film's casting. He brings a performance that is unforgettable and reshaped a complicated character, giving it the sense of madness that is normally found on the comic-books but grounded the character to our reality. Ledger had a couple of moments in the film where he had to give a speech, and he nailed all of those. I like the unpredictability in his performance as it makes his performance unique. Aaron Eckhart as Harvey Dent was great, showcasing the road to his fall of grace. I was worried that Eckhart might overplay the third act of the film, but fortunately he played it just right. Maggie Gyllenhaal as Rachel Dawes was a delight to watch. She proved better when compared to Katie Holmes as she looked more physically and emotionally tough, which was lacking in Holmes performance in Batman Begins. Gary Oldman was again great, playing this character who is physically and emotionally exhausted during the Joker murders, while still showing that aura of hope and determination. Michael Caine and Morgan Freeman are barely in the film but they still gave great performances, sometimes providing comic relief. The film consists cameos from actors like William Fichtner, Anthony Michael Hall, Beatrice Rosen, and Michael Jai White. I was surprised that Nolan was able to get them just for these small segments but nevertheless they were a delight to watch.

The Dark Knight is a perfect film, though I personally prefer it's successor, boasting great performances, wonderfully written script with amazing characters, clever direction, hard-hitting scores, and excellently handled photography. The Dark Knight is a contemporary classic.

A very well done and a personal thank-you to Christopher Nolan for making in my opinion, the greatest superhero movie of all time. The Dark Knight is hands down the best film of 2008 and is a personal favourite of mine. Everything about this masterpiece amazed me; from the engaging script to the incredible award-winning performances. It has every element you'd want from a movie, which captures you with such allure.

It had me at that fantastic moment where the bus reversed into the bank. This exposition was one of the finest; instantly roping me in with the amazing use of camera angles in the first moment and the mystery of the story and characters within these opening minutes. The film is highly script and character driven. Christopher Nolan and his brother Jonathon have written a highly complex and solid script with sharp dialogue to accompany the brilliant performances. The action and drama are perfectly balanced and is the centre of the conflict during the movie.

Although it is a follow-up from Nolan's first Batman movie: Batman Begins (2005), which is also a very good movie, this is most certainly the best Batman movie to date. But in this flick, Gotham is a place of good versus evil. There is a new villain in town and he's not playing by the rules. The Joker, played by the greatly missed legend, Heath Ledger is hands down the best thing about this movie. He wants to take over as Gotham's leader, which causes Lieutenant Jim Gordon (Gary Oldman), Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart) and Batman (Christian Bale) must come together to stop this wicked clown before he causes a time of social unrest for their city.

As for the performances, Nolan couldn't have casted better talent. Bale takes on the dual role of the Batman and industrialist Bruce Wayne. Bale proves himself in this movie and is much better than the previous actors playing the Batman role. He was a great choice of actor; being a natural and already blowing everyone out of the water in Batman Begins, he continues to bring the character to life. Although Bruce Wayne is covered beneath a mask for a lot of the time, he is still able to convey everything he needed to with just half of his face.

Eckhart plays and nails the character of DA Harvey Dent, a district attorney who wants justice and to bring down all the criminals of Gotham City. He makes Dent his own and is very admirable as a good guy. After the Joker has had his way with him, Eckhart makes us feel Dent's anger and pain through his performance as Two Face. Dent and Wayne's love interest, Rachel Dawes is played by the lovely Maggie Gyllenhaal, who takes over and gives a much stronger and better show than Katie Holmes previously. Gyllenhaal gives depth and has substance, making the audience build a rapport with her character and manipulates us emotionally into caring for her.

Leaving the best till last is the amazing and terrific Heath Ledger. Ledger gives the most outstanding Oscar nominated performance and completely steals the show. Giving me constant thrills, chills and goose bumps, his performance as the psychotic Joker is highly disturbing yet simply astounding. He created certain mannerisms (licking his lips) to define his psycho character. His voice and way of speaking was perfect for the maniac who gets kicks out of inflicting pain on others. With his lunatic laugh and malicious wicked manner, he successfully sets the tone for this dark movie about a world that has gone nuts. Ledger is a daring and extraordinary actor who perfects his character and I don't think I'll have any disagreements when I say I cannot picture any other actor who could have done a better job; the act is master class and most definitely his best throughout his career. It is completely mesmerizing. 

Putting the amazing cast and performances aside, this is a big movie. There are thrilling and intense action scenes such as the heist in the exposition and the high-speed car chases. I'm not a massive fan of action movies but these scenes kept me on the edge of my seat, completely indulged in each minute of the brilliant and exhilarating action visuals that shouldn't be missed under any circumstance. Although these scenes are captivating, even the quieter moments in the movie are equally as engaging.

The main theme in the movie, aside of good versus evil, is sacrifice and justice. Sacrifice is shown through Batman and Dent's characters where they both make self-sacrifices for the city. Batman is willing to sacrifice his good name in order to protect the people. All Dent wants is justice, and to take down the criminals of Gotham City.

I could speak and write about The Dark Knight all night. It will certainly take a lot of work to make a film that will knock this off the top spot for me; it will stand out for a very long time. It is a brilliant and chilling masterpiece that would be criminal not to watch.

As does Wally Pfister's cinematography.

Movie Prep:

This doesn't feel like your typical big budget superhero actioner. It moves at a slower more thoughtful pace. It takes its time to tell a complex story in an accessible way, and really develops its characters. At about two and half hours it's also a pretty long movie. If you're somehow new to the Batman legend, you should watch Batman Begins before taking on The Dark Knight.

Best Format:

This is massive film, and needs a massive screen to appreciate it properly. At home a HD showing is a must.

Many people comment on Heath Ledger's performance, and rightly so. But my absolute favorite scene is with Aaron Eckhart near the end of the film. After kidnapping Commissioner Gordon's family. Well, here you have it.  100% is almost an understatement.  I would put this under "modern masterpiece."  This film wasn't just Batman...it was a crime thriller. The Dark Knight is the story about Bruce Wayne, who, well should I explain it?  He's Bruce Freaking Wayne.  The billionaire who is Batman is disguise.  Bruce Wayne teams up with Harvey Dent to try and bring down the crime in Gotham.  But that means a clown comes out of the box.  Nice practical jokes, Joker!  I never thought that blowing up a hospital would count as a practical joke anymore, but you brought it back like the Twinkies!

Heath Ledger's performance as the Joker may rank as one of the best modern acting jobs of all time.  This is a list where Joaquin Phoenix, Jennifer Lawrence, and Hugh Jackman are the only ones ahead.  Christian Bale does a great job too, as does Aaron Eckhart, Morgan Freeman, Michael Caine, and Gary Oldman.  I could go on for days on how good the actors were, but I want to save your time.

Then there's the score.  Oh my god, is the score ever good!  The score made it believable, and it made it seem like a real thriller, not a superhero movie.

Which is the best superhero movie ever made? Superman? X2? Spider-Man 2? Avengers Assemble? Or any one of The Dark Knight trilogy? The answer probably depends on age and taste. What is beyond dispute is that no superhero series has come close to the scale, ambition, depth and success of Christopher Nolan's Batman films - quite simply among the finest movie trilogies ever made. The Batman franchise has come a long way since the turn of the millennium. Director Joel Schumacher had proved that with the release of 1997's Batman & Robin, he was one of The Caped Crusader's most dangerous foes. The film had met with opprobrium when released.  It was loud, manic, and more than a bit silly. The poor reception meant Warners' plans for a fifth instalment entitled 'Batman Triumphant' were shelved. That iteration of Batman was dead. Warner Brothers had one of the great movie characters but were unsure what to do with him next.New options for Batman were explored. Director Darren Aronofksy developed a Batman: Year One film and Wolfgang Petersen was linked to a Batman vs Superman movie, however, in 2002, showing how much Hollywood has changed in only a decade, a 32 year old director with only two studio features behind him successfully pitched Warners an idea on how to approach a new Batman film. Christopher Nolan had made his mark with the Oscar nominated, low budget yet extraordinary psychological thriller Memento. He'd followed up with the remake of the Norwegian thriller, Insomnia for Warner Brothers.
Although a financial success, the budget for Insomnia was a fairly modest $46m. Nolan had no experience of blockbuster filmmaking but he wanted to give Batman what the Man of Steel had already enjoyed; an origin story. Using Richard Donner's 1978 Superman as an example, he wanted to detail the motivation that drove Bruce Wayne. He wanted to chart the depths of his emotions, and the scale of his preparation, training and commitment. He wanted to show Batman beginning.
No such thing as a rebootIt seems astonishing now, but only 10 years ago, there was no such thing as a Hollywood franchise reboot. Warners were entrusting Christopher Nolan with one of their most valuable properties in a refresh that had never been tried before. It was quite a risk. But then perhaps they appreciated that Nolan was no ordinary director.Alongside co-writer and comic book expert David S. Goyer, Nolan began to thrash out the story, but time constraints meant they would have to cast the key role of Bruce Wayne / Batman before a script was completed. Angel and Bones star David Boreanaz was an early frontrunner for the role, though Warners Bros were also inexplicably keen on Ashton Kutcher for a time. Actors including Joshua Jackson, Hugh Dancy, Billy Crudup, Henry Cavill and Jake Gyllenhaal were apparently all considered. Cillian Murphy had a great audition but would be offered a different part. As David S. Goyer admitted, "Some could be a good Batman, some a good Bruce Wayne. Few could do both."
Ultimately, it was the first actor Nolan met for the role who would become his unequivocal choice. Christian Bale had just finished shooting The Machinist and weighed a skeletal 8 and a half stone. Not ideal when you have to convince Warner executives that the same man who looks like he can't climb stairs could also be an invincible ninja. Christopher Nolan got his man, and with hindsight Bale is so good, it's hard to imagine anyone else in the role. Other Batman films had suffered for every moment the Caped Crusader wasn't on screen. For the first time, the company of Bruce Wayne was every bit as engaging as that of his masked alter ego. We now had a Batman film in which Batman didn't appear until half way through. That's brave. But for the first time we had an actor who was playing a character playing Bruce Wayne. You can feel the real Bruce's discomfort at having to engage in the ephemeral playboy lifestyle to hide his secret and mask his rage. Bale's approach really was a revelation.Nolan's approach also included casting great actors in all the supporting roles. And Katie Holmes. Liam Neeson, Gary Oldman, Michael Caine, Morgan Freeman, Cillian Murphy, were all stars in their own right. This gave the film a gravitas that transcended its comic book origins. Its cast, tone, and emotional depth made Batman Begins an arthouse film masquerading as a blockbuster movie. However, despite the fevered reception and critical acclaim, the film was only a modest hit by today's insatiable blockbuster standards. Its worldwide haul of $372m was solid if unspectacular and it was only the 8th highest grossing film that year in the US. The Dark Knight Weaker, less confident studio executives might have questioned themselves and their director but to their great credit, Warners doubled down. 2008's sequel The Dark Knight was broader in scope, in tone and in budget. And it's a masterpiece. Shot in the high resolution IMAX format, the opening scene of The Joker's bank heist alone could be one of the greatest short films ever made. Heath Ledger's magnetic, mesmeric performance as Batman's most famous foe, won the tragic star a worthy posthumous Oscar (though how he didn't already have one for Brokeback Mountain remains a travesty). His Joker will forever be the definitive interpretation of that character- wry, manic, and truly chilling. It is iconic- an absolute masterclass of measured madness. It's a film that is as much crime epic as superhero film. It's thrilling, menacing, unpredictable and shocking. It had a running time of 152 minutes but was paced so superbly, it felt an hour shorter. Everything that was great about its predecessor was heightened, making The Dark Knight not only one of best superhero movies ever made, but one of the finest blockbusters of all time. The astonishing $1bn worldwide gross more than repaid the faith Warners had shown in Christopher Nolan. Then came the even greater challenge. Could a third installment possibly compete with a film that was so profitable, garnered audience approbation and critical acclaim, secured eight Oscar nominations, whilst winning two? So many other film series with two outstanding chapters disappointed when attempting a third; The Godfather, X-Men, Alien, Terminator, Spider-Man... For The Dark Knight Rises, the anticipation and hype was unprecedented. The pressure immense. Could the film possibly hit the extraordinary heights of its predecessor? The Dark Knight Rises Christopher Nolan and his team delivered the answer: not quite, but crikey, it came so, so close. Boasting an even bigger budget of $250m, Nolan followed up his crime film with a war movie. Whereas The Joker was the intellectual match of Batman, Bane would be his physical superior. He would overpower an entire city. Tom Hardy is on the cusp of superstardom, and brought his unique hulking presence to the role. It's a hard thing to cover an actor's face and ask him to emote, but Hardy is one of the most remarkable actors around. His first confrontation with Batman in Gotham's sewers is a genuinely brutal and unsettling encounter that belies its 12A certificate. Anne Hathaway too was a revelation as the dynamic and intriguing anti-hero Selina Kyle, a sharp, bewitching foil to Bruce Wayne's intelligence and strength. 
Indeed, the character and story arc of Bruce Wayne was brought to a brilliant, powerful conclusion that no bat-fan had a right to expect after the era of Joel Schumacher, and The Dark Knight Rises could not have been more satisfying. It also happened to feature one of the greatest, most rewarding endings of modern times.  Where next, Batman?
Like its predecessor, the film grossed over $1bn and enjoyed almost universal acclaim yet despite the trilogy's success, Warners find themselves with a similar, yet even more challenging conundrum than they did 15 years ago.
Where does Batman go from here?  We will know more when further plans are revealed about the sequel to Man of Steel, an ambitious Batman vs Superman movie. It's a huge challenge. Zack Snyder is the director tasked with the responsibility following the success of Man of Steel.
It may take a generation before another talented, hungry auteur is given the keys to the bat-cave, and is able to reinvent a character who continues to enthrall 75 years after his inception. Perhaps he or she is currently deep in the Tibetan mountains, training hard, honing their skills in preparation for the time when they are finally ready to accept such a mighty challenge. So many other film series with two outstanding chapters disappointed when attempting a third; The Godfather, X-Men, Alien, Terminator, Spider-Man... For The Dark Knight Rises, the anticipation and hype was unprecedented. The pressure immense. Could the film possibly hit the extraordinary heights of its predecessor? The Dark Knight Rises Christopher Nolan and his team delivered the answer: not quite, but crikey, it came so, so close. Boasting an even bigger budget of $250m, Nolan followed up his crime film with a war movie. Whereas The Joker was the intellectual match of Batman, Bane would be his physical superior. He would overpower an entire city. Tom Hardy is on the cusp of superstardom, and brought his unique hulking presence to the role. It's a hard thing to cover an actor's face and ask him to emote, but Hardy is one of the most remarkable actors around. His first confrontation with Batman in Gotham's sewers is a genuinely brutal and unsettling encounter that belies its 12A certificate. Anne Hathaway too was a revelation as the dynamic and intriguing anti-hero Selina Kyle, a sharp, bewitching foil to Bruce Wayne's intelligence and strength. 
Indeed, the character and story arc of Bruce Wayne was brought to a brilliant, powerful conclusion that no bat-fan had a right to expect after the era of Joel Schumacher, and The Dark Knight Rises could not have been more satisfying. It also happened to feature one of the greatest, most rewarding endings of modern times.  Where next, Batman?
Like its predecessor, the film grossed over $1bn and enjoyed almost universal acclaim yet despite the trilogy's success, Warners find themselves with a similar, yet even more challenging conundrum than they did 15 years ago.
Where does Batman go from here?  We will know more when further plan

MASTERPIECE

1. The Movie is Epic - The Dark Knight is not just a superhero movie. It is the first comic book adaptation to transcend the genre. Imagine one of the greatest crime thrillers of all time which just happens to have a guy who dresses in a bat costume and fights crime. Think Godfather 2 or Heat, with a insane terrorist who paints his face like a clown and goes around killing random people. It's expansive in feel and tone. It's the type of film which you make a point to refer to as a "film" instead of a "movie".

2. Bigger, Better, Longer - I'll admit that I wasn't completely blown away by Batman Begins. Sure, it was the best Batman film to date, incorporating darker themes and a sense of realism that the franchise had never seen before. But Batman Begins is also not without its problems. I think even hardcore fans would agree that the film suffers from third act problems. The Dark Knight is bigger and better in every single way. The film is 152 minutes (two hours and thirty two minutes) long, and every second is gripping. Does it feel long? Yeah. But at the same time I wouldn't have removed a thing. Every single second is necessary to tell this story. Nolan even keeps some plot developments off screen which resonate in various scenes throughout the film.

3. Heath Ledger - Some friends have expressed concern that the death of Heath Ledger will taint their Dark Knight viewing experience. It doesn't, and here is why - Heath is amazing. From the first second he steps on screen you will forget that their is an actor behind the make-up. Heath doesn't play The Joker, he IS the Joker. You will believe that a psychopath wearing clown makeup is terrorizing a whole city. The performance is Oscar worthy. What Anthony Hopkins did for Hannibal Lector, Ledger does for The Joker.

4. Two-Face - At the core this movie is not about Batman, or even The Joker, but instead about Harvey Dent, and his transformation into Two-face. In a way the story is almost a Shakespearean tragedy of a man who goes bad. The screenwriters play against the established conventions of Two-face's origin story to give you something new, refreshing, and ultimately more authentic than the story presented in the comic books. You will believe that a hero becomes the villain. And you might also be shocked at how long the two-face character appears on screen. It's not just a tease - you will get everything! His computer generated make-up is so gruesome and realistic looking, that I'm shocked the film was able to get a PG-13 rating.

5. The Empire Strikes Back - The Dark Knight is The Empire Strikes Back of comic book movies. It is dark, bleak, and realistic. Kids looking for a fun superhero movie need to look elsewhere. This is a multi-layered, authentic crime tale. There is more than one casualty, and it doesn't exactly end on a high note. Fans will eat the ending up. After sitting in the theater for two and a half hours, it will leave you wanting more.

6. IMAX - If you don't see this movie in IMAX than you haven't seen the movie. A few of the action sequences and many of the establishing shots throughout the film were shot using IMAX cameras. The result is breathtaking. There is a sequence where Batman leaps off the top of a building (you've probably seen it in the trailers) and the camera pushes in. It's so vivid and high resolution that it almost felt like it was part of one of those motion controlled theme park rides. Going into the screening, I thought the IMAX thing was probably more gimmick than anything else. Previous IMAX presentations involved up-converting the 35mm film image to fit on the IMAX screen. The footage shot with the IMAX camera is amazing. Even if you've seen a traditional IMAX movie in the past, you will be blown away by seeing a Hollywood action film on the big big screen. It makes you wonder why more Hollywood productions haven't begun incorporating the IMAX camera. I wouldn't be surprised if the inevitable third Batman movie wasn't shot completely shot on IMAX cameras.

7. Gotham City - The extensive on location filming in Chicago adds to the authenticity of Gotham City. There is never a moment that you feel like you're watching a bunch of actors on a Hollywood soundstage.

8. Characters - Every character that appears on screen has a history. Even when Nolan doesn't show us this backstory - we see it. Even a corrupt cop that has two lines of dialogue has an extensive past, at least I'm convinced they do. The world is so full of rich three dimensional characters, some of which only appear on screen for brief moments. And some of the characters do have backstories which were provided in the extensive viral marketing campaigns. If you participated in the alternative reality game online, than you will get more out of the film as a whole.

9. The Bat-Pod - You will love how the Bat Pod is introduced in the film.

10. Nontraditional - The screenplay is both multi-layered and nontraditional. I was caught completely off guard at the many wonderful choices that Nolan and Goyer made in the script. You will wonder how they got Warner Bros to sign off on the screenplay, and I mean this in a good way. Characters that you expect to die might survive, and characters you expect to live will meet their ultimate demise. Even Two-Face's origin is not exactly as you expect. That said, I advise you to stay as far away from spoilers as you can, because this is a film you want to experience for yourself in a packed IMAX theater on opening night.

To me, The Dark Knight is an almost flawless cinematic experience. Is The Dark Knight one of the best films of all time? Yes. Where does it fit in my top 10? I'll have to digest it a couple more times before my mind finds a suitable placement. Rewatchability is an important factor to me. While I do think this film will hold up to multiple viewings, I'm not sure that the expansive IMAX sequences (which are part of the reason why I loved this film) will translate in a home movie viewing environment.

The words every writer knows, and most filmmakers ought to. But not this one, apparently, at least going by the tedious soap-box "arguments" between characters which amount to little more than lazy writing.

Well, that's the boring part over - the most boring part. Visually, this film is so grimily dark, that you have to be careful you don't have a mouthful of coffee when characters tell each other how beautiful they are. No-one is beautiful when you light everyone from the side. Just because the characters are in grimy darkness, does not mean we have to be as viewers. The sound is also too compressed, making the now also tedious Hollywood "BOOMS" sound like they are held back from peaking, which strips even this tired motif of any impact.

The best character in the film (apart from Alfred) appears too late and all too briefly. Two-face's genesis is fascinating to watch but it takes too long and eats into time that would have been better spent on his blossoming and functioning as a character.

But again, at the risk of repeating myself, the characters in this film might as well turn to the camera for most of their lines, as the dialogue is for the most part a thinly-veiled attempt at reeling out the dynamics that should have been shown through actions, not words.

THE DARK KNIGHT (2008) was the Batman movie we deserved... and the one that we needed at the time... AND it's a movie that we shall look up to for decades to come because it is truly one of the best comic book films of all time. Scratch that, it is truly one of the BEST MOVIES of all time. This time around the Caped Crusader (Christian Bale still) has been working well with Jim Gordon (Gary Oldman) and Gotham City's new DA Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart) in locking up most of the city's major criminals, and overall making Gotham a safer place to live. However, their plans all go awry when a new insane criminal, the Joker (Heath Ledger), starts wreaking havoc in Gotham forcing Batman to go to great lengths to not break his rule when fighting injustice. Part II of Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, The Dark Knight is inexplicably an amazing movie that features astounding writing and direction, an amazing score, and hands down one of the best performances of all time: Heath Ledger's Joker (and it's EXTREMELY tragic that he had passed away as well). Before I go any further I have to say two important things. One, TDK was actually the FIRST Christopher Nolan film I ever watched. And two, in my opinion, TDK is the best of the entire trilogy and one of Nolan's top three films of all time.

Ultimately TDK is, in my opinion, an examination of human morals-will we always make the virtuous choice or will the given situation bend our decision and result in us doing something we naturally wouldn't do? This theme is represented mainly near the end when (SPOILERS!) the Joker plants bombs on a ship full of regular citizens and a ship full of Gotham's convicts, but puts the triggers to the prisoners' bombs on the citizen boat and vice versa; thereby now putting the people of Gotham on the battlefield, pitting them to the supreme test. Some scenes when the Joker almost has Batman even go over the limit include both the Joker's attempted assassination of Harvey Dent and the interrogation scene-the latter of which happens to be my favorite scene in the entire movie. The interrogation scene between Bale's Batman and Ledger's Joker was mind blowing awesome. A true representation of Good vs Evil, these two legendary characters just merely talking had me captivated; especially because of Nolan and his brother Jonathan's outstanding screenplay, as well as Nolan's excellent direction. I don't think I've ever seen such a marvelous yet deadly interaction of characters in a comic book movie before TDK.

And when it comes to performances, man, I don't think anyone was prepared for Heath Ledger as the Joker (if I remember correctly we all hated the decision when it was made in the first place). He was without a doubt the best in the entire movie-and he won an Oscar for the role too-from that epic bank heist to his interrogation scene; I was absolutely enthralled whenever the Joker popped up. Never once did I see even a glimpse of Ledger in that performance. Every single scene he was in was fucking awesome and I believe Ledger PERFECTLY captured the insanity and ruthlessness of the character. He had become the monster, the Clown Prince of Crime! I mean, that first "Why so serious?!" scene started to scare me! Every time he told a story of how he got his scars it showed how cunning he was despite being a complete psychopath. FUN FACT about his performance: to prepare for the role Ledger actually lived alone in a hotel room for a month and kept a diary with THE JOKER'S personal thoughts; he also experimented with voices and that maniacal laugh; and also drew inspiration from Alex De Large, the main character from Kubrick's A CLOCKWORK ORANGE. I simply cannot stop praising this incredible performance, it's just that good.

Even though I'm continuously talking about Ledger this should not discount the performances of his co-stars. Bale's Bruce/Batman is still my favorite of all the iterations we've seen and I once again say that he captures the duality extremely well here. Also his scenes with Michael Caine, who plays Alfred-Bruce's butler and guardian-were amazing. I definitely approve the replacement of Katie Holmes with Maggie Gyllenhaal as Rachel Dawes, I think Gyllenhaal is far more talented actress and did a way better job with the character too. And watching Gary Oldman's Jim Gordon: a policeman who wants to trust his teammates rather than lie to them but still ends up seeing them, his city, and even his struggling relationship with his family gradually break apart-what an exceptional performance! And now we come down to Harvey Dent aka TWO-FACE-a man who resembles characteristics of both Gordon and Batman... Yet he's actually the better of the two in terms of both morals and life goals. Personally I think Aaron Eckhart is an underrated actor and his Harvey Dent/Two Face proves why. I mean his portrayal of the character was BETTER than Tommy Lee Jones' (of course Jones was working with Joel Schumacher and we all know what piece of shit that guy put out later... Fuck Batman & Robin... and The Number 23).

Furthermore, Hans Zimmer's score is riveting and I absolutely love his theme for Batman. Surprisingly enough the Batman theme in TDK was only played TWICE within the entire movie (yeah only twice!). What's even better was the Joker's theme and every time I heard it, I knew that it was a signal. A signal that the situation was getting out of control or rather the Joker was gaining control, his chaos spreading and corrupting those around him. He was close to ALMOST having Batman break his most important rule ever. The cinematography in TDK was breathtakingly remarkable-every shot drew me in and this also adds onto the extremely well-choreographed fight sequences. Unlike the "flash editing" in Batman Begins, TDK had fight sequences in which I could vividly see who was hitting who. One of my favorites was when he's raiding Lau's building and at the very end when he's grappled out of the building and into a plane-honestly I was speechless but at the same time geeking out at the pure awesomeness at that point.

And so I declare The Dark Knight the best film of Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, in my opinion. I know there are people who love Batman Begins or The Dark Knight Rises more, but The Dark Knight wins through and through for me, large in part due to Ledger's Oscar winning portrayal of Joker. Although some of the Joker's schemes can appear to be implausible, I completely bought into the ingenuity of it all. Though, for example, at the end of the bank heist when he just randomly drives out of the giant hole in the bank and into a random line of school buses....... Overall it's a supremely well directed and well written film that continued Bruce Wayne's saga as Batman, and raised the bar in terms of both superhero movies and film making in general - 9.8/10

The following review may have some spoilers.

 2005's Batman Begins restored faith in people that Batman movies still can be very well made.The strong point of Nolan's first Batman movie was that all of it's characters were strongly built and the plot was given undue importance unlike most other superhero movies.
 The Dark Knight changed all of this,by taking the superhero movie genre in such a direction that it will be hard to surpass the level of respect that this movie has gained.The Dark Knight is not just a superhero movie-it is something even better and something which has to be watched and there is no doubt that one watching will not be satisfiable enough.
 As shown at the end of Batman Begins,Batman has to now face Joker(played by the late Heath Ledger in an Oscar winning performance),who is unarguably the best villain in a superhero movie,and maybe movies in general,till date.The Joker is not only one of the most interesting villains till date,but also a very strongly built character in the movie.The Joker here is not some clown who keeps fooling around-he actually has his own reasons which make surprisingly perfect sense if you come to think of it.There is a scene in which the Joker says that if you do things suddenly,people will lose their minds and not know what to do.He feels that if needed people will eat each other to survive in this world-and that's something he wants to prove.He wants to show to Batman how his fight for protecting the people in Gotham is in vain as they will go against him if they have to.He further proves his point by turning Dent(an amazing yet underrated performance by Eckhart)into Two Face.
 The finale of this movie is dark,gritty and unforgettable-it is probably one of the darkest movie endings a superhero movie has ever seen.The supporting cast,namely Michael Caine,Gary Oldman and Morgan Freeman,are as always in top form.
 Although I do abide by the principle that every man is entitled to his own opinion,I find it difficult to understand why this movie does not have a 100% at the tomatometer.It is not just the best superhero movie according to me(The Avengers is not even a patch on it),it is one of the best movies I have ever seen,and it is worthy of being called a classic and nothing less.

With "The Dark Knight", Christopher Nolan has once again proven himself a master of suspense, drama, and psychological thrills.  He has built upon the dark, moody, and gritty groundwork laid in "Batman Begins", and taken it to a whole new level, delivering a film with a level of sophistication never before seen in a comic-book film.  This Batman film is also a philosophical film that delves deeply into the topic of morality; what is right, what is wrong, and are they black and white?  And like the tragic heroes of Greek mythology, when faced with these decisions, Batman does not always make the right choice.

As a result, "The Dark Knight" is the perfect blend of drama, thriller, and action films.  From its brilliant opening scene to its suspenseful climax, "The Dark Knight" does not feature a single dull piece of action throughout the entire movie, and all of the action is smart, well thought out, and original.  Likewise, the twisting and intricate plot is layer upon layer of tragedy, unexpected turns, and suspenseful thrills.  Finally, much like "Batman Begins", the visual style of "The Dark Knight" is one of its many strengths.  Once again, the character designs - especially the dark, gruesome interpretations of The Joker and Harvey Dent - look outstanding.  Much like Scarecrow in the previous film, Two-Face looks incredibly terrifying, and I love how they keep teasing his transformation.

But the real highlight of this film (as you've probably heard) is The Joker.  This Joker may anger many devoted Batman fans because this Joker is no clown; he is sadistic and darkly comical.  It is a very radical and edgy interpretation, but it is the right direction for this franchise.  Not only does The Joker look horrifying, but he is INCREDIBLY well written in this film.  However, it is Heath Ledger's performance that makes this the best film portrayal of Batman's arch nemesis ever.  Heath Ledger's brings to mind Anthony Hopkins's Hannibal Lector in "The Silence of the Lambs"; cunning, manipulative, and calculating.  Lastly, and I don't know how Ledger pulled it off, but the Joker's laugh is haunting and will send shivers down your spine.

However, as captivating as Ledger's performance is, he is not the only one amongst this huge, talented cast to give a great performance.  Christian Bale once again proves to be a strong lead and improves on his performance from "Batman Begins" by giving us a Bruce Wayne with more depth and a Batman with more grit.  Maggie Gyllenhaal, inheriting the role of Rachel Dawes from Katie Holmes, does not give a moving performance, but she is still quite good.  Aaron Eckhart brings great intensity to his performance as Harvey Dent/Two-Face and serves as an excellent foil to Bale's Batman.  Gary Oldman as Jim Gordon excels in his expanded role and delivers a stirring closing monologue.  Morgan Freeman's Lucius Fox likewise is given an expanded role and is a fun presence.  Finally, Michael Caine is once again great in his fatherly role of Alfred.  This is one of the strongest ensemble casts I've ever seen.

A few months ago, I said that "Iron Man" was the greatest comic-book film to date.  That didn't last long because "The Dark Knight" is the uncontested greatest comic-book film of all time.  It is possibly one of the greatest films of all time, period.  "The Dark Knight" is a deep, thought-provoking film and an absolute must-see, regardless of whether or not you like comic-book movies.
It's a given, this is surely the greatest Batman movie ever and the most deliciously juicy meat of an incredible trilogy!

Plot/Summary,Batman and Gordon find alliance with a newly appointed DA Harvey Dent to stop a vicious killer with a warped sense of humor known only as The Joker, a threat to both the good, and the evil of Gotham City.
My Review
It isn't an overstatement to call The Dark Knight the most sophisticated and ambitious work of its kind. Superior to all three Spider-Man installments and even its amazing predecessor in terms of conceptualization, writing, acting, and direction, Nolan's follow-up to Batman Begins is a dark, complex and disturbing film, not the least of which because it grafts its heroics onto the blueprint of actual reality rather than that of spandex-clad supermen. And while such a distinction may make little difference to those already eagerly anticipating the return of the caped crusader, suffice it to say that The Dark Knight qualifies as the first official comic book adaptation that truly succeeds in being a great artistic achievement in its own right.

Christian Bale returns as Bruce Wayne, the billionaire playboy who moonlights as Batman. Having eased more comfortably into a lifestyle of excess, Wayne lurks on the fringes of his family's corporation as CEO Lucius Fox (Morgan Freeman) runs the boardroom. But when an ambitious district attorney named Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart) comes forward to challenge Gotham City's villainy through proper legal channels, the man also known as Batman sees an opportunity to replace his vigilante persona with a figure of virtue who will truly inspire the best in the citizenry.

Unfortunately, Batman's success as a crime fighter has generated new problems for Gotham, including a consolidation of the crime lords who once controlled the city independently. Meanwhile, a new adversary named The Joker (Heath Ledger) proves particularly dangerous because he seeks not only to advance the cause of Gotham's underworld, but obliterate the foundations of liberty and order that Batman protects. Torn between championing Dent and meting out justice as a masked vigilante, Wayne soon finds himself at a crossroads between being the hero that Gotham needs and the one it deserves.


Click on the image above to watch our video review of The Dark Knight.

The great triumph of The Dark Knight is that it manages for the first time ever in the history of the genre to transplant comic book theatrics into the real world - and moreover, to examine precisely what it could mean if a person decided to strap on a super-suit and start attacking the world's criminals. The first film certainly hinted at this possibility, thrusting the hero and his alter-ego into a world where Wayne's frivolity was as despised as Batman's vigilantism. But even with real-world explanations for such improbabilities as Scarecrow's ability to scare, this was still a world where the Batmobile was cool and the climactic battle took place on a speeding train as a bomb ticked toward its inevitable explosion. Here, the Tumbler barely survives its first appearance and with the exception of one or two cooler-than-cool moves that will no doubt thrill fans, its replacement/substitute - the Batpod - serves as a largely utilitarian device for Batman to get from one crime scene to the next. (That said, I still want one.)

More important than this, however, is the idea that Batman is not just a guy in a suit, but a symbol and there are people in the film - most notably The Joker - who want to destroy that symbol. While Batman's identity remains secret and his motives unknown to Gothamites, he represents hope in a city that has little to spare and embodies a pursuit of justice - and further, a code of behavior - that quite literally threatens these criminals' way of life. By throwing Gotham into chaos and testing the limits to which Batman holds himself, The Joker is not merely plying death and destruction but willfully destroying the philosophical foundations of organized society. The closest such examination another comic book-oriented film has ever attempted was the emotional throughline of the Spider-Man films. Peter Parker's struggle was almost exclusively personal, whereas Wayne not only has to find a way to maintain his moral compass, but consider what the repercussions of his heroism are to both the public and the criminals themselves.

While all of this sounds lofty - and it is - Nolan examines these themes in beautifully human terms, projecting his examination of "the hero" into the hearts and minds of his characters. Wayne, less outwardly conflicted than in Batman Begins, sees Dent's ascension as an opportunity to stop playing dress up and reunite with Rachel Dawes (Maggie Gyllenhaal) - the one woman who knows his secret. Meanwhile, Dent and his sometimes partner Jim Gordon (Gary Oldman) look at Batman's existence as a good thing, a fulcrum against which they can enforce the law and sometimes bend rules to accomplish loftier goals. And, of course, The Joker wants to destroy all of that, albeit less because of some law of movie villainy than because he sees his existence as the necessary antithesis - or perhaps ultimate extension - of the murky morality of Batman's brand of justice. When, after all, was the last time a movie criminal wasn't merely mad, but had a deeper ideological motivation for his dastardly deeds? Perhaps bolstered by the success of the first film, Nolan reaches out further with his storytelling and camerawork in The Dark Knight to create an ongoing, palpable feeling of tension that never relents through the entirety of the film's two and a half hour running time. There is a hugeness to the narrative itself, which Nolan enhances first by shooting partially on IMAX film stock (which will surely be lost to those unlucky enough to be too far to see the film in the format), but he then builds this haunting atmosphere steadily from one scene to the next, building anticipation for the moments when the violence will finally erupt.

That he occasionally veers into comic book glibness with one-liners undermines none of the intensity; on the contrary, these moments provide a release that is absolutely necessary to keeping the audience from succumbing to The Joker's febrile madness. Meanwhile, the violence is quite possibly the most intense I have ever seen in a PG-13 film, leaving myself and others wondering how The Dark Knight avoided an R. But what is more disturbing is the unrelenting menace that hovers over every scene like a dark cloud. Hans Zimmer and James Newton Howard's leitmotif for The Joker sounds like a cross between Ligeti's "Lux Aeterna" (from 2001) and the scraping, metallic curlicue that was used in trailers for The Texas Chain Saw Massacre, and enhances the clenched-fist feeling that anything can and will happen at any moment, even scenes in which he doesn't appear.

Like few other mythology-based movies, The Dark Knight truly seems to think of everything, be it conceptual or purely logical. Credit Nolan and his brother Jonathan (who also helped conceive The Prestige) for really digging into Batman's world, turning over the soil and examining its roots for possible deficiencies. While this generally speaks to the film's plausibility, they also have the presence of mind to consider such things as Lucius Fox's considerable monetary expenditures - not to mention his entire division - and how and where a paper trail might eventually lead to it. Again, however, these are not ideas or even subplots to which vast amounts of screen time are devoted, but simply revealed, explained and dealt with as they might arise in real life.

Bale is predictably effective as both Wayne and Batman this time around, playing both with greater assurance than in Batman Begins (indeed, he and his characters seem to possess more confidence). Though Wayne is a necessary second-fiddle to Batman, he is a better defined and more poised character in this film - even when he's indulging the excesses of his trust fund - and he understands the value of being in a position to help someone like Dent, be it monetarily as himself or physically as Batman. Also great is the rest of the original cast, all of whom seem as comfortable in their characters as if they'd created them themselves. Oldman in particular creates a portrait of virtue that shows a roiling well of doubt underneath, and yet always conveys effortless authority.





Meanwhile taking over for Katie Holmes, Gyllenhaal adds real depth and energy to Rachel Dawes, showing how her feelings for Bruce Wayne aren't simply unrequited, but actually based in both sincere affection and common sense. And Eckhart more or less combines all of the disparate roles he's played in the past - lout, huckster, loyal companion - into one seamless portrayal of a man determined to make things better but not quite sure how to accomplish that goal in the right way.

Finally, there's Ledger, whose performance I suspect will be the subject of many analyses of all sorts in the weeks and months to come. What he does with The Joker is, quite frankly, nothing short of transcendent. Early in the film he explains the origins of his trademark facial scars, and you worry for a moment that the filmmakers are giving this psychopath some kind of convenient explanation, which, talented though he was, Ledger won't be able to overcome. But by the third time he's explained where they come from - each time telling a different tale - you realize that Ledger was a master of his craft, only in his final years finding roles that truly offered him the chance to explore that mastery. His is the definitive movie Joker, and he owns the role and achieves a level of abject insanity that is terrifying as it is irresistible.

Overall, the film does maintain a steady pace and function with such continuously unnerving momentum that it occasionally seems like a second installment. (There are plenty of appropriate comparisons to other sequels its quality mirrors, if not possibly surpasses: Toy Story 2, The Empire Strikes Back, The Godfather Part II, etc.) In fact, so well-executed is this film that even the title - or at least its true meaning - seemed to catch its audience off guard, until it gets explained, expertly and poetically, at the very end of the movie.

A screenwriting professor of mine once said that what happens in a story must be surprising but expected, and Nolan's approach to The Dark Knight epitomizes this maxim. He gives you exactly what you want, but does it so well that it manages to completely catch you off guard when it happens. But there really is no better way to describe The Dark Knight than to call it a great work of art because it transcends both the boundaries of comic book moviemaking and even the parameters of good filmmaking. What Nolan and Co. have created doesn't just function as a thrill ride or even a terrific movie, but rather as a substantive and philosophical examination of why we need heroes, and then when we need them, what they mean.

The Dark Knight's screenplay was written by Christopher and Jonathan Nolan with story contributions by David S. Goyer. The writers have written a spectacular film that touches on themes like justice, morality, trust, chaos and order. They have taken these themes and wrapped it around a battle between two individuals who are fighting for Gotham's soul, and I found this idea to be very interesting. It was finally exciting to see someone that can truly go up against with someone as strong and symbolic as Batman. The first film addresses the importance of Batman acting as a symbol for Gotham, to protect Wayne's loved ones and to create an idea that is indestructible, but the writers contradicted that here by conjuring up a similar being that nobody could understand and boasts polarizing values causing cracks in Batman's values and legend. This allowed the writers to have stakes for the protagonist to be much higher and eventually involving members of his personal life. Underneath the surface, lies a couple of sub plots that keep us interested between the big moments. One of these sub plots include the romance between Bruce Wayne and Rachel Dawes, which didn't feel forced and was only used in order to show the audience another shade of Wayne and an apparatus tool for the main plot. I was actually surprised on how they handled this romance, because action-oriented films tend to really force it in and it brings the film down. The film also carries the ideas from the first film about trust and corruption, indicating that Gotham is still being plagued by this and the people who are idealistic, particularly Jim Gordon and Harvey Dent, are finding it hard to create progress towards restoring the image of Gotham. The film's dialogue is definitely a step up from the previous film as it is much more well written, I think it had something to do with Jonathan Nolan being involved with the writing process, and it doesn't seem to be as pushy anymore in being clear with it's themes and messages. It is more concerned with driving the film along and creating tension, while still giving it a layer of depth that is present to be explored if one is interested to search for it.

The film was directed by Christopher Nolan who, by the film's release, has already proven to be a notable director but this was the film that made him the important director that everyone now claims him to be. Though I agree with this praise, I don't agree that this was his strongest film as I felt that his next two films were his masterpieces, at least that's how I feel about them for now. Nolan has created a film that proved that films within the comic-book genre can be serious and that it can stand against or with the greatest films of all time. There was issues I had with the first film that was fixed here and one of the main ones was the city itself. The first film treated the city as just a setting for the story to take place, though it did try to create the world through having important citizens be present on screen, it just wasn't enough. Nolan corrected this by having multiple characters who are not really that important be more involved with the film's plot, some of these include characters like Ramirez, Maroni, Mayor Garcia, Lau, Chechen, Reese, Commissioner Loeb and Mike Engel. Their involvement makes the world of Gotham more convincing and it allows the setting to become a character of it's own and show a sense of "character development". Nolan also made the decision of using more of locations during exterior scenes rather than use sound stages like Batman Begins; making the world look more convincing and natural. This was also the first time where Nolan has shown his ability to handle something so ambitious. He really made great use of the studio's budget and combining it with artistic license. Nolan has improved upon the action from the first film by making them bigger and ambitious. He also widened the scope of the film by having scenes be shot from different countries and backdrops. The action was not entirely original but they were great in creating tension and excitement from it's audience, particularly the warehouse sequence and the final showdown between Batman and Joker. I felt this film was well paced, definitely an improvement from the previous film, balancing excitement with storytelling. Nolan wants us to be completely invested on what is happening on screen. The film's editing wasn't as erratic as the first film, particularly with the action sequences. Nolan has managed to show most of the scene's choreography and still manage to create that feeling of tension and intensity that was necessary to sell the scene.

The film's director of photography was Wally Pfister, a common collaborator of Nolan. Pfister has changed the look of the franchise, giving the film a more natural look as compared to the first film that had a brown palette and a dirty look. I found this approach to be much more favorable as it didn't try so hard to be noticed. Pfister has placed all of his focus instead on the performance of the actors, the storytelling and creation of beautiful shots. As this film is a performance driven film, particularly for Heath Ledger, there was emphasis on capturing it and ensuring it retains that intensity until the scene is over. The film also contained beautiful helicopter shots and action sequences which were shot with IMAX cameras capturing wonderful detail and colors that 35mm probably couldn't achieve. It's too bad that I wasn't able to watch this in an IMAX theater as it would have probably blown my mind. Like Batman Begins, Pfister went back and forth with the erratic hand held approach, found mostly in action sequences, to the steady hand-held/mounted style used primarily in dialogue driven moments. It is much more controlled here with Pfister being more confident with his style of shooting. Pfister also allowed the choreography to be more in display which was essential in selling the action-oriented scenes.

The film's score was composed by James Newton Howard and Hans Zimmer. It still features the great epic score from the film's predecessor and combines it with a couple of new compositions that are just as epic as the main theme. Both composers were able to create tension through the heavy use of strings. They were able to create this sense of chaos and unpredictability with the score, particularly when the Joker is on screen; there is this presence of a screeching note symbolising the madness in this character. The composers were able to create this weight to the story with their score, making it feel like it's bigger than just an action comic-book film.

The acting in The Dark Knight is much better, than compared to Batman Begins. This may be due to better written characters and a story that demands more from the actors. Christian Bale was fantastic as Bruce Wayne. His performance here feels much more natural and more entertaining to watch. It's the moments between Bale, Eckhart, and Oldman that showcases the best of his performance. Heath Ledger was definitely the gem in the film's casting. He brings a performance that is unforgettable and reshaped a complicated character, giving it the sense of madness that is normally found on the comic-books but grounded the character to our reality. Ledger had a couple of moments in the film where he had to give a speech, and he nailed all of those. I like the unpredictability in his performance as it makes his performance unique. Aaron Eckhart as Harvey Dent was great, showcasing the road to his fall of grace. I was worried that Eckhart might overplay the third act of the film, but fortunately he played it just right. Maggie Gyllenhaal as Rachel Dawes was a delight to watch. She proved better when compared to Katie Holmes as she looked more physically and emotionally tough, which was lacking in Holmes performance in Batman Begins. Gary Oldman was again great, playing this character who is physically and emotionally exhausted during the Joker murders, while still showing that aura of hope and determination. Michael Caine and Morgan Freeman are barely in the film but they still gave great performances, sometimes providing comic relief. The film consists cameos from actors like William Fichtner, Anthony Michael Hall, Beatrice Rosen, and Michael Jai White. I was surprised that Nolan was able to get them just for these small segments but nevertheless they were a delight to watch.

The Dark Knight is a perfect film, though I personally prefer it's successor, boasting great performances, wonderfully written script with amazing characters, clever direction, hard-hitting scores, and excellently handled photography. The Dark Knight is a contemporary classic.

You know, I disliked this film at first, thinking to myself this isn't what Batman is about. But once I read the comics the film is based on I learnt to appreciate and fully understand that the film IS actually what Batman is all about.

The Dark Knight is directed by Christopher Nolan and is the sequel to The Batman Begins.
In this destructive, evil, gripping movie, the Batman meets his arch rival, the Joker! Nothing is better than an intense rivalry between two foes who fight back and forth to control Gotham. Nolan evolves his characters, acting, and action to give the movie its thrilling rivalry between two foes.
The characters that are created and portrayed in this movie have an everlasting effect on how viewers will know and view the Joker. Many thought that the Joker could be nothing more than a villain who creates havoc and destroys things. The Dark Knight really gives a whole new perspective to any villain charcter. From the outside the Joker seems messy, crazy and diabolical, which is the form of any good villain. Once we see how he operates and how he goes about daily routine of destruction do we really see just how "funny" he can really be. The Joker has a whole new form, the whittey comments, his body language and his pasty white face with his scarlet red smile he is nothing less than a true villain. All of his components have created a monster for Batman to try and stop. Nothing is more dangerous than
a villain who just doesn't give a crap about anyone or anything. In many scenes we see the Joker put his life on the line many of times to prove a point. He doesn't care if he lives or dies as long as the other person is in pain and humility for the rest of their lives.
Good acting wouldn't be good enough for this film. Great acting would be good enough, but superb acting is what is really needed for this film to fly and that is why the Batman is about to do so. Christian Bale plays two roles, the Batman and Bruce Wayne which require two different styles. As Bruce Wayne he acts as a smart yet clueless playboy who only knows how to throw around money and women. In the scene when talking to his friends about the Batman Bale has to act like he isn't a fan and portray that he is clueless about the Batman who he knows more than anyone else. When he switches over to the Batman character he must be the dark, serious crime fighting vigilante. Going from moneyman Bruce Wayne to scary, hardcore Batman takes serious and not so serious skills.
Nolan does a great job in capturing every moment and every explosion necessary to complete
this film. Every action and explosion scene was created and filmed in such a way that nothing was left out. The different vantage points taken in order to capture the detail of the explosion and the characters reaction was spot on. Nothing is better than seeing the whole picture. During the scene where Harvey Dent is being transported, the Joker uses explosions and gunfire to try and kill him. Nolan uses different camera angles to to capture every angle. We can see every explosion and every character's reaction to
the events that unfold. Nothing is lost when it comes to Nolan and his cinematography work. From Harvey inside the bulletproof truck, to Batman inside the batmobile, to the Joker and his goons shooting everything in sight, Nolan creates a thrilling and gripping movie that doesn't let you go until the very end.
Creating a sequel is not only hard, but risky. Everything needs to stay the same, but yet have its own way. That is why Nolan is the best and this movie is the best. Not is this sequel play of of the first one with its own twist and turns it is even better than the first which cannot be said for many sequels. Nolan takes not only his skills and technique, but everyone elses to create an insanely dark and humorous movie. At the end of the movie all he wants is to put a smile on that face.

I love what Christopher Nolan has done with Batman.  The only problem for me is that, unfortunately, I don't like Batman in general.  Even if Stanley Kubrick had made a Batman film at some point, I most probably wouldn't have liked it.  But that isn't anyone's fault but mine.  I just can't take the concept of costumed men fighting crime seriously - let alone, ones that put on silly, gruff voices, and use their wealth as an excuse to ride the most ridiculous vehicles imaginable.   I haven't actually seen the other two properly - and the only reason I sat through this one was because everyone went on about it so freaking much.  And I would be lying if I said I didn't like it.  Contrary to what I say when discussing this film with others, I did think there were many great scenes in 'The Dark Knight'.  I won't bother listing any, because then I would feel obliged to mention the other parts which I didn't like so much.  Suffice to say - and this is strictly my opinion, which I understand is in the minority here - that I thought the film mostly hitched its success via the quirky performance from Heath Ledger.  I won't be a dick and say, "Oh, people only love him because he's dead now," - that's bullshit, because Ledger was excellent - but I will say that I think they cheated in making the villain the unofficial hero - and he totally was.  The movie was all about The Joker - people remember only The Joker - they should have called it: 'The Joker Comes To Gotham'.  As far as I know, DC Comics hadn't intended on having Batman overshadowed by his enemies.  And yet, that is exactly what happens here.  But whatever, I'm not into Batman, they can do what they like with him.  At the end of the day, 'The Dark Night' is still an excellent movie.  I just don't like it, and so I'll give it three stars ... out of humble politeness, and the acceptance that I'm probably wrong.

Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight is the middle film and the pinnacle of his trilogy. Besides being the greatest comic book movie of all time, it is simply a great movie regardless of genre. When I saw it in 2008, I actually ruined my first experience. I could not resist looking at some pictures and reading a little bit about the storylines beforehand and pieced together too much of the plot. Nevertheless, I was able to fully appreciate the near perfection of the movie the second time I watched it. To date, it is the only movie I have watched that got significantly better the second and subsequent times. The Dark Knight has everything you want in a movie: exhilarating action sequences, great plot, and fantastic characters. Of course, the star of stars is Heath Ledger, who stole the show as the Joker and posthumously won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor. As we know, Ledger died six months before the release of the movie. After Jack Nicholson's iconic performance as the Joker in Batman (1989), few thought that his Joker could be topped. I was definitely among the majority who thought the task was impossible. However, Ledger proved me wrong and blew Nicholson's performance out of the water. Ledger's version of the Joker will forever be the face of this movie and is the main reason it receives so much acclaim. In Ledger's own words, his Joker is a "psychopathic, mass murdering, schizophrenic clown with zero empathy." While I will not say it is impossible again, I find it difficult to believe that anyone will be able to top Ledger's Joker. The one criticism that I have heard about The Dark Knight is that it has too many climaxes. However, it is like saying something is so good that you cannot believe it. As such, you need to subtract a couple of points just to be safe. I respectfully disagree.

For my full review, please go to http://rookerville.com/2013/07/23/retroactive-review-the-dark-knight/

The Dark Knight is the sequel to Batman Begins stars Christian Bale as the hero we all know. When a new player starts taking over Gotham's mobster groups and eliminating public figures, Bruce Wayne has to find a way to stop him. 

By this point, everybody has seen this movie or at least knows of the hype behind Heath Ledger's iconic performance as The Joker. I won't fanboy over it more than this: nearly eight years (10 days away from turning 8 years old at the time of this review) and many viewings later, Ledger is still mesmerizing in this superhero flick.

Truthfully, the performances across the board are terrific. Maggie Gyllenhaal replaces Katie Holmes from the first installment as Rachel Dawes, Bruce's longtime friend and love interest. Gyllenhaal's performance might as well be legendary as well when compared to Holmes' lifeless take, so I was pleased. Once again, Michael Caine as Alfred, Morgan Freeman as Lucius Fox, and Gary Oldman as James Gorden are all solid. I especially enjoy Caine's take on Alfred - witty yet subtle. The music score is fantastic, as is usually the case with Hans Zimmer, and the movie was well-shot and edited. I also really liked the VFX for Two-Face's half-burned face.

Now, The Dark Knight is not flawless. Christian Bale does solid work as Bruce Wayne, but the direction either he or Nolan decided to take with Batman was frustrating. Batman, while tactically brilliant, is terrible in hand-to-hand combat, which can be blamed on the stunt coordinator as well. Worst of all is the HORRIBLE BATMAN VOICE. It's been mocked for years for good reason.

There are also some weird plot points that I couldn't get passed. How did Joker set the egg timer to the EXACT moment when police officers would fire their guns at the funeral? How did Joker know that it was time to call in to the night show to threaten a particular life when he was nowhere near a TV or his henchmen? Why did Bruce use his Batman voice when in a room alone with Lucius, who knows his identity? Little things like that pop up throughout the movie that, when noticed, pull the audience away from the action.

Overall, I do love this movie. It's easy to get nit-picky with superhero films, but hey, I have high standards for my Batman flicks. While not as purely enjoyable as Batman Begins and a bit too long (2.5 hours), The Dark Knight is worth watching for Ledger's performance alone, and it's worth watching again for the sheer enjoyment of the lore.

Final Grade: B

The Dark Knight is about the same idea as Batman Begins. The idea that justice trumps vengeance. The Dark Knight takes this idea to extremes to suggest that justice is an ideal that must be protected at all costs. It demonstrates this idea with the main plot of Save Gotham's Soul. This is supported by an internal plot that takes place within Harvey Dent, his seeking of revenge or justice, which is irreversibly broken when the Joker kills his girlfriend Rachel. Joker's actions ruins Harvey and Rachel's chance at love and sets Dent on the path to destruction. Finally, Batman is not only the main driver of fights to save Gotham, he also sacrifices his reputation to Save Gotham's Soul. Thus, the idea that justice is an ideal that must be protected at all costs is demonstrated. Justice as an ideal must be protected even with Rachel's death, with Dent's false hero status, and with Batman giving up his reputation.

It's a great story and a triumph of movie making in the age of fluff and crap. Too bad the final part of the trilogy, The Dark Knight Rises turns out to be as empty as this one is full.
