The Dark Knight is a transcendent film, it goes beyond any kind of genre classification, and it is also one of the greatest films ever made. It is much more than a typical superhero film, it actually sets the mark for what a superhero film can be, but more than that, it is a masterfully crafted thriller that is also a Shakespearean tragedy. It is so hard to pick out what is the best part about this film, because the direction is near perfect, the script is fantastic, the cinematography is stunning, and the acting is absolutely remarkable. Nolan proves to everyone that he is one of the best writer/directors alive with this film, he and his brother, Jonathan, wrote the screenplay for it, and they have written a character driven film that makes us look further into the shady nature of right and wrong, and the psychology that makes each person tick. But the first character that I have to speak of is The Joker, both Heath Ledger and the Nolan brothers succeed at making one of the most sadistic and anarchic characters ever to be in a film. He is a mass murdering nihilistic psychopath, he literally wants nothing besides terror and chaos, money means nothing to him, and lives don't mean anything, possibly the only thing that does matter to him is the game he is playing with Batman. And I like that the Nolans chose to use that element of the character, because that is really all that has fueled The Joker throughout the history of Batman, his only goal has been to make Batman break his only rule and give in to the chaos that he has created. The Joker is the greatest villain ever invented to compliment his hero counterpart, and The Dark Knight shows us why, he and Batman are not just a good vs. evil duel, it is an endless game of one trying to break the other, and neither ever succeeding, in short, it is the greatest good vs. evil parable ever told. And not just because it is emotionally gripping and entertaining, but because it is probably the most accurate representation of how the two mingle in this ever-changing world, it shows us the vagueness of what is good, and the absolution of what is evil, which is something that The Dark Knight makes very clear to us. However, The Joker would not have been as truly terrifying and human if Heath Ledger had not given everything he had into the role, there is no instinct for self-preservation in his performance, he devotes himself so thoroughly to his role that it is as if he actually became as insane as The Joker. Honestly, it is very hard to even tell that it is Heath Ledger, his voice, body language, and the look in his eyes are not the same as the Heath Ledger we have seen in other films, they are something that is far more sinister and vindictive than anything else we have seen. But Ledger's performance is not the only one to be praised, Eckhart, Bale, Caine, and Oldman all gave terrific performances that would be gold in any other film, but Ledger just stole the show, it truly is one of the best acting performances I have ever seen. To conclude, The Dark Knight is a film that will appeal to everyone, but it is a film that will not be properly appreciated by its audience for its artistic expression.

Overall, Nolan has crafted a phenomenal, gritty sequel that features a surprising amount of depth and works on every level imaginable.

The superhero movie genre, for all its innovation and accomplishments, will probably never receive the respect or recognition that other genres enjoy amongst professional circles, which is somewhat odd considering that even something as lacking in resonance as The Graduate can achieve placement on the American Film Institute's top 100 films list. This was evident in 2009 when, in the most overt joke of an Oscars ceremony, the second entry in the modern Batman trilogy was not considered for the coveted best picture award, with a nomination inexplicably going to The Curious Case of Benjamin Button. This was not the first example of an excellent film being snubbed (Hoop Dreams suffered similar treatment in 1995), but then again the Academy's actions are not the subject here. 

This is something I am only saying after giving it a good amount of thought: The Dark Knight is one of the great movies of all time. The reason I am bold enough to say that is because, plainly, it stands at the pinnacle of its genre. I believe most any genre, with a few exceptions, is capable of producing greatness, and no one would have to think too hard to realize that. There are animated classics, horror classics, comedy classics and even giant-monster classics. The superhero genre being unable to achieve similar heights is simply ludicrous to me. But, excellent quality is not sufficient to achieve what I am talking about. What makes The Dark Knight a classic in its own right is that it transcends its origins and reinvents the possibilities of what a movie of this type can be. 

The story of the film, ultimately, is about consequences, a theme that is rarely explored in these adaptations. Batman's actions cause the mob to unleash the Joker on the city, leading to all kinds of casualties. An idealistic district attorney becomes corrupted, a city turns against its defender, the hero loses his hope for a normal life and is even tempted to break his own moral code, all consequences of one radical move against crime. It is this running theme that makes this sequel an effective follow up to the events of its predecessor, while at the same time presenting its own distinct story, and a rather strong one at that. More so than any other film starring the titular character, The Dark Knight explores the inherent difficulties that a superhero faces in trying to eradicate organized crime from a place as corrupt as Gotham, taking a few unexpected turns along the way. It draws you into this world that, while not exactly realistic, feels somewhat plausible due to the overall treatment of the material and depth of the screenplay. 

One of the most interesting aspects of the film, in my eyes, is actually the setting. While it lacks the style and gothic architecture of Tim Burton's 1989 film, it is nonetheless a more brooding and dangerous place. One of the things director Christopher Nolan deserves credit for is bringing the city of Gotham to life like never before. We finally get an idea of the people of the city and what they are going through, such that Gotham becomes a character itself that is just as dynamic as any member of the cast, and in this film it appears more stable than before but quickly reveals an undercurrent of danger. We get to see how everyone is affected by the situation: the elite, the civilians and the criminals. There is a very real sense of paranoia and distrust that pervades the city, conveyed well by some of the conversations. My favorite is the one between Harvey Dent and Rachel Dawes over the phone after Gordon's supposed death. This is fitting, as it brings us an idea of what it would be like to work in such a corrupted city. All of the 90's live action films failed to capture this, which is just one testament that The Dark Knight, along with its two companion pieces, boasts a nearly unprecedented understanding of the essence of the world of Batman. Of course, there has to be some action sequences but thanks to the art direction and cinematography they are more potent than one would expect. Unlike in The Avengers, when there is an explosion here it really feels like something bad just happened.

As anyone who has seen it will attest to this is a very grim motion picture, but this in and of itself does not guarantee quality, which is a misconception that is unfortunately too common. That would sustain the notion that a film like Return to Oz is better than The Wizard of Oz. What matters is whether such a tone is faithful to the spirit ofwhat has been adapted. With Batman Begins a fittingly serious approach was taken with the material, yet the feel of a comic book remained. The Dark Knight pushes the envelope in this area and includes some genuinely chilling scenes. Many involving the villain fall into this category, but two that I believe deserve mention are Alfred's recounting of an incident in the Congo and Harvey Dent's very questionable interrogation of a random thug. With the former you get an idea of how great the approaching threat is, and the latter is impacting because of its contrast to what has already been seen of Dent. For a moment, we are reminded of his ultimate fate.

	The cast is consistently excellent, although the reception to it carries a bit of irony. Unlike with Iron Man, where the lead performance was so good that most were willing to overlook that the rest of the cast was generally unimpressive, the villain's performance here is so good that most fail to recognize what impressive work the rest of the cast brings. Bruce Wayne's tale of a very troubled man who was driven to do something unconventional is expanded upon to cover the times where he begins to doubt whether his methods and decisions were justified. This contributes to what is one of the most insightful portrayals the character has seen in an adaptation. The same can be said for much of the supporting cast, particularly of Michael Caine and Morgan Freeman as the voices of reason in Bruce Wayne's life, the former being very effective in several somber scenes. Because of this, the relationships within the film are surprisingly well developed and intricate. Harvey Dent does not have much respect for Wayne, but admires Batman. James Gordon initially trusts all of his allies, but grows more desperate as that trust seems increasingly misplaced. All 3 of these people sustain the trials of this crisis and by the time the final scenes come it is fascinating to look back on what drastic changes have taken place. But the most notable dynamic in the film is, of course, that between Batman and the Joker. The conflict between these two is eventually revealed to be more than one of interests: it is one of ideologies. Both are haunted individuals who have experienced something grave in their pasts and have been driven to extreme actions. Yet, they are polar opposites battling for the soul of a city. One believes in the salvation of that city, the other seeks to prove that it will never come. The original 1989 Batman film had the potential to mine an interesting hero/villain dynamic, given that in that adaptation these two were responsible for each others existence, but that was pushed to the side in favor of typical comic-book thrills. With The Dark Knight, we understand exactly why these two will not kill the other and how it is they regard one another. I think it is interesting that out of all the people in the film, the one with whom the Joker is most honest is Batman.

Contrary to popular belief, this is not exactly a thought provoking film. You won't find the answers to some of life's big questions here, even though there are some neat insights into the nature of heroism and the tendencies of people. This is rather a movie that uses ideas to simply tell a story. When the characters make the claim that elected officials are preferable to outlaws it is not a statement on social matters, it is supposed to create a plausible dilemma for the hero. In other words, this tale is told with uncommon depth and intelligence, and it speaks to us because "these stories touch on deep fears, traumas, fantasies and hopes", as Roger Ebert put it. 

If I had to pick out any problem, it would be that the rescue portion of the climax goes on a bit too long and suffers from the type of editing that makes it easy to lose your place during the action if you let your mind wander for a moment. It is not as engaging as some earlier sequences, but is redeemed by the final confrontation between the two combatants and a knockout falling resolution. Even so, this is a comparatively minor misstep and the people that worked on this film can continue their careers with the assurance that they helped bring what remains the strongest superhero film to date and one of the best sequels ever made.

There's a new villain in which we don't know too much about, his name is the Joker played by the scary looking Heath Ledger who looks like he's wearing unwashed chemical paint on his face where we 're oblivious how it got their or that theirs is no real background revelation except to say that he's psychotic and loves to create fear- this was very evident when he burns up the currency after robbing one of Gotham's biggest bank's as well as execute any of his goons who sought it.   And the reason why I say that The Joker is not quite developed here is because on the first Batman movie "Batman Begins" the two super villains shown and introduced are somewhat self explainable who are Ra's Al Ghul and the Scarecrow. "The Dark Knight" is the pinnacle of superhero movies and a masterpiece of any genre. It is one of my favorite all time movies for many reasons. The level of sophistication in this movie and its adult themes leave all other movies in the genre in the genre. The intertwining character arcs propel the plot. The most heartbreaking of these is the fall of Harvey Dent, played by Aaron Eckhart. Batman (Christian Bale) and Gordon (Gary Oldman) complete a triad of "good" characters who are forever changed by the mechinations of the Joker, played by the phenomenal Health Ledger. Ledger is not just acting; he is channeling something very dark and frightening.

"The Dark Knight" is of course exciting and action-packed, but the dialogue is sharp, the plot is insightfully modern, and the outcome is devastating. The modernity is present in the scenes set in Hong Kong, an acknowledgement of just how central China has become to both the movie industry and geopolitics. There is also an exploration of surveillance in our society and the lengths society will go to keep the status quo. What Batman becomes at the end reflects these complexities and our modern conception of heroes, anti-heroes, and villains.

But maybe I am not hyping this movie enough. The supporting characters are all given something important to do, including the members of the mafia and other criminal organizations in Gotham. The Joker's reign of chaos is as much aimed at the criminals of Gotham as it is against authority and society. What he accomplishes by the end of the movie forces Bruce Wayne to an entirely different level of hero, but not without great cost. This is not a movie where the hero wins and the villain loses.

What makes this one of the greatest movies of all time is the full repertoire of emotions, tones, and themes that Nolan deftly constructs into a complex journey without an easy ending. There are scenes of suspense and tension as horrifying as anything in horror, exhilarating chase scenes, several moments of thoughtful reflection, difficult decisions made by complex characters, heartbreaking losses, witty humor, the best moments between Bruce and Alfred yet, an opening and an ending that flow smoothly and inevitably, and a bewildering number of themes grounded in the complexity of unfolding events in a huge modern city.

Will there ever be another superhero movie that works on so many levels and transcends its genre? I am actually pretty doubtful. There have certainly been subsequence superhero movies that I have rated 5-stars, but although they are among my favorites, they don't rise above the trappings of this particular genre in the way that "The Dark Knight" does. Even "The Dark Night Rises," although a satisfying conclusion to Nolan's extraordinary Batman trilogy doesn't quite reach the heights of this movie.

Years and many viewings later, "The Dark Knight" remains to me an astonishing achievement in the history of film, and it continues to point to the future of filmmaking.

If Batman Begins reinvented the character of Batman on the big screen, then The Dark Knight reinvented the superhero genre as a whole and solidified this series' success, imprinting itself in the memories of countless moviegoers everywhere. The Dark Knight is one of those few great films that takes its genre, reinvents it as something we'd never seen before, and subsequently sets the standard for every movie of the same genre that comes after at (until another film comes along that's just as revolutionary, if ever). Just about everything that was good about Batman Begins is here and then some, whether it's the characters, acting, storyline, special effects, action, and etc. Christian Bale is once again fantastic as a gritty and realistic Batman. The rest of returning cast (Gary Oldman, Michael Caine, and Morgan Freeman) are all great as well. But what really makes the film shine is the late Heath Ledger's portrayal of The Joker, which is absolutely immersive and brilliantly acted to the point where Heath Ledger almost ceases to be himself and becomes the character entirely, and subsequently, is and always will be the definitive live-action Joker (Take that, Jack Nicholson). Aaron Eckhart is also great and somewhat underrated as Harvey Dent/Two-Face, transitioning perfectly from good to evil after his disfigurement, which speaks for his duality as an actor. The only real weak aspect, once again, is the female lead of Rachel Dawes. This time around however, they've recast Maggie Gyllenhaal as the character after Katie Holmes decided she wasn't coming back to the series. Now I've never been a fan of seeing recasting in a role because it just feels wrong to me, but if the replacement actor does well, I can justify and even forgive it. However, even though Katie Holmes wasn't that good as Rachel to begin with, Maggie Gyllenhaal somehow manages to be even worse; being even more bland and uninteresting than Holmes was. At least Katie Holmes as Rachel Dawes was attractive enough so that I could believe Bruce Wayne would fall in love with her, but Gyllenhaal doesn't even have that going for her (I cringe every time I watch the scene where the Joker calls her beautiful). She's so bad and forgettable that I was honestly kind of glad when she gets blown up (I know, that makes me sound like a bad person but I bet you felt the same way too). And ultimately, her bad acting can't get in the way of how epic the film is. In the end, I think it's safe to say this is the best Batman movie ever, one of the best sequels ever, and even the best superhero movie ever; just a triumphant masterpiece of modern-day cinema.

There has never been a perfect Batman film and there probably never will be. What The Dark Night trilogy gave us though were three coherent, original, yet each distinct pieces of the Batman puzzle each with their own ups and downs.

This instalment is the most revered and in many ways that's understandable but  its not without its flaws. You'll be lucky to find any flawless film out there but its worth taking a step back from the hype with this one, not just to get the clearest picture, but also out of respect for this, quite brilliant, film.

It deserves to be harshly judged because from the opening minutes till the very final ones it demands respect and makes clear to all that it aims to be memorable. The only way to treat a film like that is to try and be critical of it because it deserves more than being great on credit alone, it deserves to prove that its great.

That was me shedding the last of my Batman-intensity for now- it comes and goes. So, as a follow up to Batman Begins it is superb- an improvement in every way aside from the fact that there's less space for it to breath because there's more expected of it and more given in the shape of a frantic plot. 

As the middle instalment in the trilogy its also superb- each film offers a different stage in the process and in many ways, this middle film, is the main course. Its greatest strengths are probably its plot, cinematography and performances. Despite being heavy on content the story is always coherent and interesting- it flows well, develops and expands well and still has enough space to breath and leave something for the next instalment. 

This is almost solely due to Nolan's wholly original ability to influence a script with such finesse that  dramatic and, often movie-dominating plot-twists can be incorporated with relative ease. Its a slight of hand that occurs again and again and allows for endless elements to become incorporated into one film without it ever losing its natural development.

Of course, with so many successes in that field in this one film its hard not to be left wanting more and one or two elements can't help but feel crammed in at their final stages of development. Its never rough or coarse in that way but it leaves us with a selfish disappointment in that we know we've had more than enough and yet we still want just that tiny bit more. Sadly, this is an issue that carried on into the final film. 

The clearest example of this is Dent's progression into villainy- it feels too contrived and begins strong before trickling down into one of the weaker sub-plots. This is through no fault of Eckhart's performance or from the character itself, as its a favourite of mine. The fault lies in the script simply not being able to deliver goods from every angle, which is entirely understandable with something as ambitious as this.

Dawes is also a weak area, feeling more like a token female love interest than a real part of the story with her only real role being to speed up Dent's progression as fast as possible. Again, I don't blame the performance from this- Gylenhaal's style isn't for everyone, but I think she gave a solid performance and feel that the issues lied more with her character, dialogue and general positioning within the script.

The performances as a whole were strong but I've found the trilogy to be over-cast in this film and the final instalment. The first film already had a star-studded cast and casting Katie Holmes and Cillian Murphy in it also gave it a strong middle-ground and allowed Murphy to really stand out. (I feel his performance has been overshadowed by Ledger and then Hardy but in many ways Scarecrow is equally as strong a villain) 

I feel that the next two films removed this middle-ground and simply replaced it with more well-known names. I understand the need to keep things fresh and I enjoyed the performances but it comes close to turning the series into a novelty, a franchise folding under commercial pressure. That's the very extreme of course but more realistically- just by having Freeman and Caine in there you've got a supporting cast that's stronger than most films' lead cast. 

Speaking of the lead cast, we have two pretty dynamic performances here. Firstly, Bale continues to deliver what we've been waiting for in a Batman but I find his performance in the next instalment to be far superior, he progresses throughout each of them and he gets it spot on in the end- the voice is finally just right and the movements are more fluid while also wielding more power. Nonetheless, he delivers here and does what he needs to with, an actually quite minimal part in the film. That sounds silly but there's seriously little real dialogue in the part this time round and Wayne is a relatively simple character at this point in the series- out of the three, I feel that this is the one where Batman actually takes a step to the side, surely just because of how much is going on.

Ledger's performance is great and he makes The Joker his own while paying tribute to those in the role before him. He steals every scene in which he appears and its clear that that is the film's intention- this one was always going to be about The Joker. 

I don't believe Ledger's performance has been overrated as some have argued- I see his influences *cough* Tom *cough* Waits *cough* and I see the unique subtleties that take the performance well-beyond the call of duty- I dare say that most other actors would not have been able to make The Joker such a success had they been cast in the role. While he steals his scenes, I don't believe that he steals the film at all and that's because the other performances are powerhouses too which is no surprise considering that the likes of Oldman and Fichtnerare involved. Heck, if any performances didn't rise up, I'd have to say they were Freeman's and Caine's- they just felt completely safe in what they were doing, they weren't pushing themselves in the way that the rest of the cast did- most people are out of their comfort zone with something like this but it felt like Freeman and Caine were put right into theirs- a weakness with all three films is the achingly simple portrayals of Fox and Alfred- they receive some of the strongest dialogue in the films but they tend to feel like 'acting breaks' in-between the intense action of plot development of other scenes. Glorified motivational speakers for the most part in this one and it feels rather unnecessary especially considering how well Oldman can carry that torch himself.

The visuals of the film are great though I have a few issues that I generally seem to be the only one bothered by- with the faster action scenes some of the editing is very slightly awkwardly-paced with the timing of the camera changes sometimes being noticeably off, at least for me anyway. 

In trying to create realistic fight scenes I feel that it slows down too much at times- the fighting looks and feels great but as its rarely one-on-one the surrounding characters seem too in place, waiting for their cue which kills the realism a little. One example is when Batman breaks in through a window, does a forward roll, runs to the next room, disarms a man and then takes him down. It all looks great and slick yet powerful but there's two other men, all the while pointing their guns who could at any moment shoot- they are right by the window, they could shoot him before he is on his feet and yet they literally pause until the other man has been disarmed- the scene was just too ambitious for the format and when you contrast it to other scenes where the lighting is darker and the space is more restricted (the club scene for instance) everything works perfectly. Its a strange problem as I don't recall it being an issue in the other films but I've seen this one several times now and it always feels a bit off to me.

Another issue was the use of CGI- in creating that gritty realism throughout, CGI is hardly used and that's great but it means that when it is used its very obvious and off-putting, it doesn't help that even technology from as recently as 2008 already feels outdated compared to new films. The film is overly-flashy at times too, particularly with the batbike (can I call it that?) but the vast majority of the action in this film is very well done.

The bike scenes when the driving is close up are stunning and the Batmobile/truck/SWAT scene is astounding. These along with powerful punches, (that are great without resorting to gore) generally great camera work and the sinister streets of Gotham as epic as always, makes this a real visual-treat.

There are other issues that I could point out but saying more would just be trampling over the successes, which I haven't covered in nearly as much detail- simply wouldn't have time. The fact that I've been so extensive about the issues is proof that the film is so great, its problems need to be explained well and justified so as to be fair.

Its a mighty genre-transcending piece that rightly has its place as a classic and I wouldn't be surprised if it continues to thrive, many, many years from now. I am generally not a super-hero movie fan and for this one to do the franchise such justice while appealing so much to me is another thing worthy of respect. Its too grand a film for me to really love- I'll always prefer something more bare and minimal but that wouldn't suit this trilogy and it wouldn't have made it the success that it has been either.

I love comic book films. There were the 3 Iron Man films (all of which I loved), The First Avenger, Thor. But I don't consider The Dark Knight a comic book film. 2012's The Avengers is a comic book film. It's cartoonish and action-packed. It had aliens, battlesuits, gods, other realms, and other things that aren't real. The First Avenger had a bright and shining agent of unlimited power in the shape of a cube and had us believe Steve Rogers survived getting frozen (Even if he was a superhuman, his blood and pulse would also freeze along with his physical self, therefore killing him.) Thor had the obvious theme of magic and supernatural gods. I could also add Sam Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy and Marc Webb's The Amazing Spider-Man to the list of comic book films above. Both Raimi's and Webb's versions had an awkward teenage boy getting bitten by a radioactive spider. What all these films had in common were they had unrealistic set pieces. As unrealistic as they were, these films were more loyal to the comics they used as a basis. The most realistic of the movies above were, in my opinion, Iron Man 3 and The Amazing Spider-Man. Iron Man 3, instead of displaying the Mandarin to be an old man with magic rings as his weapon, showed him to be a terrorist leader. The Amazing Spider-Man became more loyal to the comic and at the same time became more realistic by, instead of Peter's spider web coming from his wrist, showing that Peter's spider web came from a wrist device that Peter invented. Then again, Iron Man 3 had the fiery superhuman bit while The Amazing Spider-Man had a man turn into a mutated, hulking lizard-man. Now, I'm not saying I didn't like all those films. I loved every single one of the films mentioned above except Spider-Man 3 (which I would downgrade to "kinda liked"). I just think that these films are inferior to The Dark Knight. I don't consider The Dark Knight as a comic book film. In fact, to any critic's review, positive or negative, that says that The Dark Knight is a comic book film is a review I'd have to agree to disagree with. I even disagree with the critics consensus with that one bit where it says this movie succeeds as a comic book movie. It doesn't. This film makes Daredevil, Elektra, and The Fantastic Four look like Superman (1978), The Rocketeer, and The Mask of the Phantasm in comparison if you're talking about how great this film is as a comic book movie. In the Batman comics, Batman goes against monsters and magic. This film isn't loyal. It changes how the Joker and Two-Face became who they were, it continues to choose a completely fictional character (Rachel Dawes) to be a main character, and most of all, Bruce Wayne does a Sam Elliott impression every time he dons his costume. No, this film isn't a comic book film. It's a superhero film. It uses comic book characters, but it's not about comics. It's about heroes.

Here is The Dark Knight's best film set pieces in order:

1. Story
2. Characters/Performances
3. Script

Let's talk about the script. The Dark Knight follows The Big Lebowski as the most quotable movie of all time. The script was brilliant and it created a very serious and ghoulishly brooding overtone for the film. Serious and brooding overtones aren't necessarily good. Just look at Daredevil. But it made The Dark Knight different from older versions of Batman. It separated Christian Bale from Adam West, Val Kilmer, and George Clooney. It separated Aaron Eckhart from Tommy Lee Jones (who is still really, really awesome by the way). It separated Maggie Gyllenhaal from Kim Basinger. It separated Heath Ledger from Cesar Romero. This overtone made the Joker gleeful and terrifyingly villainous in a way that was more powerful than Jack Nicholson's Joker (But I think both Ledger's and Nicholson's versions were equally great in their own ways. And Jack Nicholson is still really, really awesome). Now let's talk about the characters. I've met some people who thought Heath Ledger's performance was only universally acclaimed out of respect for the dead. Which in this case, was unfortunately Mr. Ledger himself. RIP, by the way. But in my opinion, Ledger's suspense-inducing and horrifying portrayal of the Clown Prince of Crime is up there on the Greatest Film Characters Hall of Fame along with The Dude, Walter Sobchak, Travis Bickle, Ed Wood, Gerry Boyle, Agent K, and many others. The rest of the cast was also spectacular. Christian Bale brought depth into the character of Batman in a way even the other good Batman (Michael Keaton) never could. Aaron Eckhart was a really great villain, and he makes the viewer feel sad that Harvey Dent became a bad guy because he could've been a much greater hero. Michael Caine and Morgan Freeman are amazing as usual. The characters are a very big part of a film. Films with great characters like The Big Lebowski and Magnolia are enough to make them both marvelous, entertaining, and unforgettable. Similarly, the characters of The Dark Knight are one of the major reasons this film is phenomenal. Finally, there's the story. I will tell you of a film that had great visual effects and a great performance from its main star. That film was Oblivion. The positive things RT counted from Oblivion was the special effects and the performance of Tom Cruise. But what critics didn't find present in it was a good story, which was most likely what led to its rotten rating that's ever so close to a fresh one. The story of The Dark Knight took genuine storytelling and actual elements from the comics and put them into one book. For example, the comic The Killing Joke exchanged between two story lines: Batman trying to save Commissioner Gordon from the Joker's new bad guy plan, and the backstory of the evil yet mysterious clown prince of crime, the Joker. The Dark Knight's story was more similar to the former. The Joker's current plan for Commissioner Gordon was to put him through a day of true Hell. Joker captures the Commissioner's daughter, Barbara Gordon (AKA Batgirl), and shoots her through the spine, crippling her. In my opinion, that has to be Comic Book Joker's most villainous deed since he beat Jason Todd with a crowbar and blowing him up with his biological mother. Anyway, Joker's plan in The Killing Joke was to show Batman that anyone, even the sanest person on the planet, can turn into a lunatic through a day of pain and torture. In order to show Batman that, he cripples Batgirl (also turning her into her other heroine persona, Oracle), strips her naked, takes pictures of her bloodied and exposed body, captures Gordon, strips him naked (I don't know what's up with that), and sends Gordon through a roller coaster of Hell. During the ride, he is surrounded by pictures of his daughter's bloodied body all the while getting laughed at by the Joker's creepy henchmen and being subjected to the forced listening to Joker's impromptu jingle about insanity. The Joker expects Gordon to be insane at the end of the ride, but the bad guys never win. Similarly, the Joker does this to Harvey Dent by getting him captured, having half of his face burned off, and killing his fiancée (who had just accepted his proposal). Although unlike Commissioner Gordon in The Killing Joke comic, Harvey's sanity gave in, and soon turns into another infamous Batman antagonist, Two-Face. While some people might find that too bleak, I find it to be another realistic element added by Christopher Nolan because it shows that not everything ends with a happy ending. Which of course this film certainly did not. Anyway, this film is my exact example of a perfect film. If my scoring system was similar to IMDB and I can use decimals, I would still give this film an exact 10/10. No, not a 9.7/10. Not a 9.8/10. Not even a 9.9/10. My score would be 10/10, no matter what. In other Batman media, such as the animated Batman TV shows, if you see a flaw in the realism of it all (such as Batman knowing exactly where the villain's secret lair is or how he can move so quickly from one place to another), one can easily respond, "BECAUSE HE'S BATMAN!!!!". With Mr. Nolan's version, you couldn't do that because in the Nolanverse, Batman wasn't using teleporting machines or rocket boots. He had military technology, but compared to everything he's used in other media, the weapons he used in the Nolanverse were nothing. He also didn't have his supernatural and extraterrestrial friends like Superman or Green Lantern. If an ultra powerful force were to attack Gotham, he wouldn't have help from them. If he dies, he can't be resurrected. It's like with James Bond and Die Hard. What Daniel Craig's Bond did was that it modernized one of the oldest characters and excellently settle in James Bond into a modern world where there aren't any exploding pens or invisible cars. Daniel Craig modernized Bond, like what Nolan did to Batman. The first Die Hard was loved by people not only because it was an action-packed and witty film, but also because John McClane was an everyman. An ordinary joe. Besides that, he was trapped in a building full of terrorists and hostages, meaning the police couldn't just bust in anytime and help John. He had to save everyone by himself. Also why some people didn't like the fourth one and why most people didn't like the fifth one. At that point, John was a Jason Bourne. He seemed like a superhuman who could survive anything and lived in a world where anytime, he can just call people for help to defeat the bad guy. Like Die Hard, in the Justice League or the Brave and the Bold animated series, Batman paired up with Superman, Green Lantern, the Atom, Green Arrow, Plastic Man, and many others. In the Nolanverse, sure, he had Lucius Fox's machines, he had help from Gordon, and he had help from Catwoman and the rest of the GCPD in TDKR. But like Batman's weapons, compared to Batman's other superhero partners, Fox, Gordon, Selina, and the police force were nothing. So overall, Christopher Nolan made Batman's life much more difficult. But still, The Dark Knight is a masterful and well-crafted spectacle for both Batman fans and non-fans, and words cannot describe, in my opinion, how true the words, "The Dark Knight is the greatest film of all time." really are. Well, all I know for sure, it's true enough to make this amazing film my one and only absolute favorite.

Just as the supreme surprise that was 'Batman Begins' is about to close, Jim Gordon gives Batman information about a guy: "Take this guy. Armed robbery, double homicide. He got a taste for the theatrical like you. Leaves a calling card." Batman turns the playing card over, sealed in an plastic evidence bag, to reveal a Joker card. It was probably the greatest tease in any comic-book movie and previews what is to come. But it doesn't prepare fans for the sheer experience that would soon be 'The Dark Knight'. Countless words were used to gush about it and here are a few: Legendary blockbuster cinema. This was arguably the greatest superhero film of all time and I can't disagree with that. It takes 'Batman Begins' and takes it a whole new level! It delivers everything you'd hope for in terms of action, then delivers on a whole other level as well. Deep down, the film tackles the very essence of not just superhero movies but any essential dramatic feature; a psychological dissection of the nature of Good and Evil, and the perilously fine line that often separates the two. And it encapsulates all this in an crime saga that's richly-layered, intelligent, and uncompromising. 

Much of 'The Dark Knight' immense success can be pinpoint to one standout achievement: Heath Ledger's Joker. Fans were skeptical but were ultimately blown away by Ledger's completely transcending performance. It is the greatest villainous performance because it elevates everything around it in the movie. The character after all is the most dangerous and dastardly villain to bring chaos to Gotham City to begin with. From the subtle mannerisms like the twitch of his eyes, the quick lick of his lips, the hunched shoulders to the eerie voice and dread inducing dialogue, Ledger's performance is arguably THE crowning achievement of any superhero movie. Jack Nicolson gave a great performance of the same character in 1989's 'Batman' but like all the other Batman villains before 'Batman Begins', he comes off as a hyper violent cartoon character. Ledger gives us a scarier, grounded, and definitive Joker in which he delivers the true essence of the character. He is not a rational gangster or greedy mustache twister with a lot of motive; he is a straight-up psychopath who kills & induces fear because he "just wants to watch the world burn". The infamous bank heist prologue in the very beginning establishes the character perfectly in itself ("I believe that whatever doesn't kill you simply makes you...stranger.) but that's not all. Most all his scenes mesmerizes, like where the Joker describes how he got the scars on his face, you realize that each story might be a lie. The mystique of the character elevates his menace with razor-sharp tension and unpredictability permutating the film. May Heath Ledger rest in peace because his acting career had only begun!


Putting aside the Joker, the rest of the film still excels on many other levels and surpasses its predecessor. Between the two films, a year has past and Batman seems to have reached his prime rather quickly; a symbol of fear for those who pray on the fearful. But throwing Joker into the mix, Bruce Wayne is faced with a new set of compelling challenges that will shake him to his core. Bale's performance is terrifically understated, often overshadowed by Heath Ledger but no less worthy. That interrogation scene between Batman & the Joker...pure cinema! Much of the Joker's crimes puts quite a psychological toll on Batman and the people of Gotham but none are more impactful than on District Attorney Harvey Dent. This is where the movie gets its most emotional arc. Dent proves to be a really good man, a bright light of hope in Gotham who will put everything on the line to get justice; a man that Bruce is inspired by his dedication and earnest idealism, even as that same man wins the heart of his love interest in Rachel. Aaron Eckhart gives a strong, spirited & ultimately tragic performance that makes the ending all the more earth-shattering. Maggie Gyllenhaal is a good replacement of Katie Holmes as Rachel. She seems tougher, more lively and more in sync with the fellow actors. I cared for her much more and I was shook when she is killed off. Her death breaks Harvey which makes him susceptible to the Joker's twisted philosophy ("You know the thing about chaos? It's fair."). The rest of the cast, including Gary Oldman, Morgan Freeman and Michael Caine, are outstanding. But if there was one performance that I wasn't quite impressed by is the Italian Mob guy, Chechen (Ritchie Coster), mainly because I found his accent horrendous.

If there is one thing that standouts about the film is that every set-piece feel like one show-stopping climax after another. It can be exhausting but also exhilarating to watch it all pieced together, thanks to Nolan's brilliant screenplay, Wally Pfister's masterful cinematography and Lee Smith's taut film editing. For a 2.5 hour film, 'The Dark Knight' flies by and never drags! Some might be boggled the movie's hyper-active structure but it really makes the twists in the story positively volatile and nail-biting to the end. Again, some moments of the pulse-pounding action sequences are a tad incoherent, but its not an issue as its probably moments that are representative of the Joker's state of his chaotic mind; which is also represented in Hans Zimmer/James Newton Howard's electric music score. CGI effects is minimal but rendered to perfection. Harvey Dent's burnt half of his face is all CGI and it looks so damn realistic and gnarly. The sets are quite epic too; They built an entire hospital (outside shell) to blow up. The gadgets are better than ever and Batman's suit gets a clever upgrade. I could really go on forever about 'The Dark Knight.' It is dark, complex and unforgettable. As Batman realizes he must live on to become the villain so that Harvey Dent's legacy can heal the scorned city of Gotham. Expectations were incredible high for the next film and I doubt that there will be any superhero movie to surpass for decades to come.- 10/10 (A+)

The Dark Knight
	I began watching Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight last night and thought that this was the best version of the Batman movies I had ever seen. The reasons I might think Christopher Nolan's Batman movies are the best ones I have seen are probably because of: the actors/actresses, technology, and story. 
	In The Dark Knight, there are a few new characters/villains added to the story. These new characters are the District Attorney Harvey Dent (Aaron Eckhart), The Joker (Heath Ledger), and Two-Face (Aaron Eckhart). Although Batman is the main character, the movie does focus a lot on the Joker and the chaos and destruction he causes, which is a vital part of the movie, because without the Joker's mischief being shown the movie would be pretty boring. 
	In this movie we don't only see the Batmobile (also known as the Tumbler) again, but we see something new, the Batpod. The Batpod, was used after the Tumbler took some major damage. It was incredibly cool and one of the most badass motorcycles I have ever seen. It has dual front mounted cannons, machine guns, and grappling hooks. Apart from the new vehicle Batman got, he also received new armor that allowed for better flexibility and mobility. This helps for a few reasons and the most important one being that he can actually turn his head like he would without the suit and not have to turn his entire body if he wants to see something next to him or behind him.
	Besides the new characters/villains in the movie that we are introduced to we have characters from the last Christopher Nolan Batman movie, Batman Begins. We have Lucius Fox (Morgan Freeman), Rachel Dawes (Maggie Gyllenhaal), Alfred (Michael Caine), and Captain/Commissioner Gordon (Gary Oldman), and most importantly Bruce Wayne/Batman (Christian Bale). These characters help make the movie what it is, the movie is absolutely amazing.
	I personally think Christian Bale's performance in this movie was pretty good, but the performance of Heath Ledgers was better. I even think that Heath Ledger's Joker was better than Jack Nicholson's Joker. They portray two different types of Joker, but Ledger just blew me away with his performance. I know in previews of movies they will claim so and so gave the best performance of their career, which is bullshit most of the time, but this was his best performance in his entire career.
	All in all I think the movie was amazing. The action, story, and humor really shined in this movie. Nolan is doing a phenomenal job with creating the new Batman movies. I can't wait to watch The Dark Knight Rises next.

'The Dark Knight' is one of the year's best films. And it's the best superhero film of all time. Although, it's more closely related to crime-drama than superhero. Never have we seen a psychological masterpiece as haunting and deeply disturbing as this one. The story is simple: Batman (Christian Bale) must battle the ruthlessly evil Joker (Heath Ledger in an Oscar worthy performance). With that set up, director Chris Nolan moves this movie into thematic territory never before seen in a superhero movie. The Joker is so evil and so psychotic that he needs no motive to do the things he does. At one point he tells Batman, "You won't kill me out of some misplaced sense of self righteousness, and I won't kill you because, you're just too much fun." At another point in the film, he makes the mob share half their money with him, and then he burns it in front of them. The film is filmed with dramatically confounding scenes like this that leave your jaw dropped to the floor, unable to move. The unnerving sense of satanic evil exuding from this character is so frightening, it rivals the greatest screen villains in history. In fact, Ledger's Joker may be the greatest villian ever to be put on the screen. Licking his lips at the excitement of causing psychological dilemmas and ultimatums for his victims, his make up smeared, he never fails to make our insides churn with disgust. If he isn't nominated this coming year, I'll be shocked, as I will if the film isn't nominated for Best Picture. Because it is. So far anyways. Neck and neck with Wall*E. The Joker isn't the only enemy in the film, and here's the film only flaw: Two face. The character can never be completely plausible. He works much better here than he ever has before, (avoid seeing Tommy Lee Jones in a horrible portrayal of Harvey Dent/Two Face in 'Batman Forever'), but he wasn't written as genuinely or as intrigueingly as the Joker was. However, his scene at the end of the film is intensely frightening, and the dark beauty of is motivs is somewhat gratifying. The Dark Knight works on every other level. The writing, the cinematography, the editing, the music, the acting, everything. Maggie Gyllenhaal is great as Rachel Dawes, and Morgan Freeman, along with Michael Cain and Christian Bale give A performances. Director Christopher Nolan has made a masterpiece. A film that transends genres, that doesn't take cheap shortcuts are gimmicks, a film that genuinely wants us to suffer along with the victims of the Joker's horrible deeds, and that suffering is both heartbreaking and extremely satisfying. The Must See Film of 2008 is The Dark Knight.

Show me a better movie and I'll show you a purple dinosaur that can handle a sniper rifle. WOW. This is an incredible movie. It's dark, thematic, complex, action packed and emotionally stimulating in that order. Batman Begins was about expounding and developing upon Batman's character, The Dark Knight is about doing the same for the Joker's character. To a child watching the movie, the Joker is the epitome of pure insanity, but anyone who really understands the movie and what Christopher Nolan is trying to convey understands that what makes the joker truly frightening is that he's actually very smart and has some plausible ideas about humanity. The main thing he wants to prove is that everyone is corruptible and the presence of random injustice means there is no "justice." The interesting thing to me is that both the joker and Batman experienced traumatic events in their childhood: the joker had an abusive father and probably dealt with other horrible things, batman watched his parents die in front of him as an eight year old. Yet, these two could not be any more different-they are, in fact, complete opposites. The joker represents chaos and the Darwinian idea of Survival of the Fittest, meaning that he thinks there should be no rules since humans are by nature selfish and incapable of truly following rules designed to promote compassion. Batman, on the other hand, has a tremendous amount of faith in people and their ability to love and be selfless for the good of the human race. One could argue that even being " selfless" is selfish because it brings a satisfying feeling to the person who performed the compassionate act. However, in my opinion, the fact that it may be selfish to be selfless doesn't detract from the value that doing something for another person carries. This a paradox of humanity: by helping others you're really helping yourself. One of the reasons I love Bruce Wayne is because when he experienced tragedy he decided to dedicate his life to trying to protect others from tragedy, which is an incredibly admirable thing to do. The joker, on the other hand, said " well, my life sucks so I'm going to show everyone how bad people really are deep down" which is not an admirable thing to do... but anyone with an open mind must admit that the joker presents truths about the nature of people. He was able to corrupt Gotham's " white knight" in Harvey Dent and hence won the battle against batman by showing him that even the most honorable person is capable of evil. However, there are things in this movie that show the power of human compassion. For example, when the prisoner throws the detonator to the bomb ( which will kill the good people of Gotham and save his boat from being blown up) out the window the power of good defeats the forces of human greed. This was an incredibly powerful scene that made my jaw drop. The reason this movie is so much better than The Avengers is because The Avengers is just a mindless movie about beating up aliens. This movie presents ideas about humanity and makes the audience wonder " if I were in that position... what would I do?" This is a thoughtful movie for thoughtful people.

Although I saw this movie a few months ago, I felt the need to review it before The Dark Knight Rises, so here it is.As the first sequel of the newest generation of the Batman franchise, The Dark Knight takes it to new and deeper level of perception on the world of organized crime, while keeping a solid grasp on the superhero's roots. The caped crusader continues his war on crime within Gotham City alongside commissioner Gordon, with the new lawman, Harvey Dent, introducing new methods to help catch and convict the crooks. Their joint efforts succeed in most of the city's seedy underbelly, although the rise of a new sinister villain, the Joker, puts the trio to the test when he threatens to force Gotham into anarchy. Brooding characters and visuals are effective in upping the ante for both Batman and the city, and story offers up a new and darker rendition of the Joker than the one previously seen in the 1989 Batman. The director also utilizes a larger scope for this one than in the previous installment, Batman Begins, enabling us to see bigger consequences for the character's actions and the moral choices that cause them.

Heath Ledger delivers one of the all-time great film performances in Nolan's epic of crime and politics. There are occasional bits of groan-worthy dialogue and gaps in logic galore (particularly the Batman-as-martyr ending), but the flaws are transcended by great storytelling in the service of big ideas. I never get tired of watching that interrogation scene.

A madman has brought his wrath to "Gotham City" (Chicago, Illinois) which is finally cleaning out the criminal element. That man is known to authorities as "The Joker" (Heath Ledger). And there is only one man who can stop him -- a masked vigilante known as "The Batman" (Christian Bale).

However, another man is trying to do, legally, what the "Caped Crusader" has been doing. That man is the District Attorney "Harvey Dent" (Aaron Eckhart), who eventually becomes what "Bruce Wayne" (Bale) fights to become in his dark alter-ego.

The two men who are trying to get "The Clown Prince of Crime" each have the same partner -- "Lt. James Gordon" (Gary Oldman), who is one of the only uncorrupt cops on the force. But, "Batman" has two more partners in his battle against evil -- "Alfred" (Sir Michael Caine), the "Wayne" family butler and "Bruce's" life-long confidant. "Batman's" other partner is the CEO of "Wayne Enterprises", "Lucius Fox" (Morgan Freeman), who is the man behind all of "Batman's" weaponry.

First of all, let me say that this movie is, in my opinion, as close to perfect as you can come. Especially compared to movies I've seen recently. There are way more pros than cons if you ask me.

First of all, most of the movie is just a little too bright for the world of "Batman." The scenes set during sunlight were just not dark enough to set the right mood for this world originally created in DC Comics. Personally, I would have liked to have seen dimmer lighting in many day scenes where the lighting could be controlled.

Like in the last film, I really had a problem with the "Batmobile." It looked more like a military vehicle, and not something "Batman" should be behind the wheel of. Yes, it's painted black, but every version of the famed vehicle always reminded you of a bat in some way.

I also had a problem with how some of the characters were used. First of all, this movie, like all in the genre, expects the audience to know the background of the main characters for the most part. I still have a problem with Caine, an Academy Award winner, as "Alfred." I just can't picture him as a butler, and he was barely used in this film. Personally, I wish he and Morgan were in the film a little bit more -- especially Caine since Morgan was in the film a bit more often.

Despite the weak writing of the characters, I found the performances pretty strong. Heath Ledger, who died shortly after filming this movie, is almost perfect as "Joker". He captures the insane tone of the character very well, and completely brings you into the performance. Bale is really good as "Batman," although I thought his voice for the character was a bit much. He really did a good job as "Wayne" though.

Caine and Morgan, though under used in my opinion, did a great job with what they were given. You really felt that "Fox" knew why "Wayne" wanted the equipment, but knew not to ask. I also thought Caine made "Alfred" more a father-figure than a butler. In fact, I can't even remember one time when he acted more like a butler.

I was almost impressed with Eckhart until he became his evil alter-ego, "Two-Face." It wasn't until his change that he really picked up his performance.

If you ask me, Maggie Gyllenhaal had no chance at making "Rachel Dawes" her own. She had to fill the role created by Katie Holmes in "Batman Begins", and really didn't do anything that made you forget Holmes in the first movie. In fact, she just didn't make me feel for her when she met her fate in the film that was used as part of "Dent's" dive into madness. They tried to make her look like Holmes, but only made her look like a younger sister to her.

Of course, there is a lot of action in this film. These scenes are fast-paced, and done perfectly. These scenes are edited very well, and get the job done. Another special effect which stands out is the "Two-Face" make-up, which is actually CGI edited over Eckhart's face in post-production. It wasn't until I saw some production stills online that I thought it was some very elaborate makeup.

The music was done really well in this movie. Although I couldn't tell you any pieces of music used if I heard it again, the music really enhanced scenes. Like the soundtrack should, the music was used perfectly.

I wouldn't put this in the top five of your "Must See" list, but I would suggest that you check this one out the next time you find it on HBO, or even the next time you visit your local rental store or Netflix.

For what seems like all of Batman's history with Hollywood, even with Nolan's previous effort in the Batman Reboots--Batman Begins--the original caped crusader has been forcefully cast "into the light". He wasn't the dark, brooding, human being that became his signature in the comic books. With Tim Burton's "Batman" and "Batman Returns" there were dark elements to the story, but the dark themes were never as all-encompasing as they should have been with the character himself. In a way, Batman in Hollywood had grown a false stigma of being very one-dimensional. Things certainly weren't helped when the atrocious "Batman Forever" hit theatres (let's pretend that "Batman & Robin" never happened, and spare Schumacher  the shame).

Enter Christopher Nolan. Fresh off "The Prestige" and "Batman Begins", he's already proven his adept ability to take a simple story and wrap it around your mind, involving you mentally and emotionally into his movies. With his brother Jonathan Nolan and himself as the primary writers--not having David S. Goyer to weigh them down--they've finally succeeded in bringing the character of Bruce Wayne to the screen with intimacy, intensity, and darkness.

With Gotham finally recovered from the failed attack Ra's al Ghul and his League of Shadows, Batman has reached the absolute height of his power. The mean streets of Gotham are beginning to run cleanly again, and Batman's fight seems to be coming to an end. With the Gotham Police Department helping him track down the last remaining mod's assets, Bruce Wayne is having more issues with amateurs following his example than tracking down the criminals themselves.

But Batman's plans continue to put the mob in tight places, cutting of their escapes one by one. Clinging to the last of their blood-money with desperate hands, they've run out of options. In their haste to keep their power in place they finally decide turn to help. That help is a single man. A man with green hair and crude makeup, who is as insane as he is intelligent. The absolute worst kind of criminal. The Joker.

And so it begins.

The beauty that Nolan has drawn to the Batman saga isn't just about a human being that has evolved to become the perfect hunter. He has become a vigilante, in every sense of the word. Being hunted by both parties, good and evil, has caused him to rise to a neutral status: he does what he does for the sake of all. He is not the judge, jury, or executioner, and refuses to be such. And the Joker, manically insane and so perfectly performed by the late Heath Ledger, is his polar opposite: doing evil for evil sake, and finding entertainment in the sadistic, darkly comical every day plans he makes. Fighting such an enemy is more than a challenge to Bruce Wayne, who not only fights as Batman but fights as himself as well. He no longer wants the life of a vigilante. He wants to retire, fall in love, and live life. Defeating the Joker is his final trial. The last push to cleanse Gotham--and retire the Batman--for good.

Christopher Nolan makes pulls no punches in constructing Bruce Wayne's fight, taking the story of the Batman and turning him into the legend that Gotham needs. With the Joker hot on his tail, literally burning buildings down in order to match him on the battlefield, Batman must push the very limits of being Gotham's guardian. And choosing what matters to Bruce Wayne, the Batman, and the city, will change the identity of Batman forever.

Christopher Nolan?s 2008 film sequel The Dark Knight is a sick and twisted tale of the battle between a broken Batman and a depraved killer, The Joker. The movie is quite disturbing in the exploration of the mind of the murderer and his affect on the general public. Nolan brilliantly builds endless suspense with a fast paced plot and complex characters. The interest sparked in the audience is caused by the performance of The Joker by Heath Ledger. His complete disregard for society?s morals and his constant ability to force people to make horribly gut-wrenching decisions makes the audience uncomfortable and worried about the destruction he will cause Gotham City. Even the way he speaks in a calm, all-knowing manner is too strange for such a horrid being. Peter Rainer of the Christian Science Monitor further gives insight into The Joker, ?Ledger doesn't offer the audience the slightest glimmer of hope or hilarity. His motto is a sick-joke variant on Nietzsche: "Whatever doesn't kill you makes you stranger." Nietzsche had it as "stronger," and that applies to the Joker as well: He's fortified by awfulness.? This awfulness behind the Joker is what pushes the film forward in such an intriguing way. The Joker?s strange mind is a driving force in Batman?s internal battles that also keep the viewer guessing. The film is a troubling look into the chaos that will ensue if a major city was ever attacked by such a ruthless villain. The extremes of human nature are symbolized in the sadistic acts of the Joker and the hope trying to be spread to keep the people safe. http://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Movies/2008/0719/p25s04-almo.html  

Being an avid fan of Nolan?s take on the Batman comics makes my opinions are slightly biased. As much as I love taking on a debate about a complex movie, there are some things that you can?t really argue. Things like whether or not all elements of the Batman movies are realistic. Adam Nayman of Reverse Shot made comments in his review of The Dark Knight about how many of the scenes are improbable. At the beginning of his article Nayman states, ?the general tone of the film, which is heavy on psychologizing but light on actual plausible psychology.? Although I?m not a true psychologist, I know enough to believe that a lot of the psychology behind the movies is understandable. Like in the scene when the two ferry boats are each given a detonator. One boat holds innocent citizens while the other is filled with prison convicts. They are given the choice that either one boat blows up the other, or both will be blown. It turned out that neither boat was able to make the choice to murder the boat of other people. This psychology is highly understandable. A majority of the population cannot handle the thought of playing god and being responsible for taking someone?s life. So even though the scenario may be far-fetched, the psychology behind the people?s decision is completely understandable. Another point made by Nayman is the dark nature of the Joker. Nayman expresses his feelings that ??Ledger?s performance, which is easily the least comic screen take on the role to date, but it also points to why this incarnation of the character is so unsatisfying.? In this statement, Nayman shares his opinion that the Joker in The Dark Knight was the most wretched portrayal of the character he?s ever seen. He says that this creates an unsatisfying personification of a known killer. Personally, I think that this is a completely false idea. In Nolan?s Batman Trilogy, the stories are much darker; they revolve around the disturbed mind of Batman and his enemies. To me, this is where the Joker gets his appeal. His creepy, sadistic persona and twisted schemes form the film into a worrisome tale about how people will react to a tragic situation when they have a hero to turn to. Even the way the Joker switches the story about the origin of his scarred face, gives him so much psychological dimension. The Joker?s extreme darkness is what solidifies his character as so intense and interesting for the audience to become engaged in. Overall, I completely disagree with Nayman?s characterization of The Dark Knight as a ?flawed and overrated movie.? In my opinion, the film is interesting and complex, and the wickedness of the characters creates an engaging dystopian story. http://www.reverseshot.com/article/dark_knight

As a film, "The Dark Knight" is not as infallible as people make it out to be. The problems are there, but they seem to be overlooked due to the focus on Heath Ledger's performance and the overall darker, more realistic nature of the film. Before looking at its problems, however, I want to acknowledge and discuss what's great about it.

One of the most significant attributes of this film is its dark, realistic tone. It's arguably the first major super hero film that tried to look at what might actually happen if a diabolical villain terrorized a city. In reality, he wouldn't waste time doing fanciful super villain deeds; he would simply start killing people until the hero took off his mask. And that is what the joker did. Indeed, this change of tone has done more than just satisfy its audiences; it has changed contemporary filmmaking. Have you noticed the darker tinge of all the recent super hero films? Have you noticed the villains getting more frightening and the storylines getting more complex and realistic? That is all due to this "The Dark Knight."

Secondly, Heath Ledger's performance is fantastic. It is the foundation of the film, and, let's face it, the real reason people love this film. In the end, it's not Batman or Harvery Dent that makes us come back to see it again and again; it's the Joker, with his combination of psychosis and intelligence. 

Finally, the film's score obviously had a lot of work put into it, and it does a good job at not only supporting the overall tone but also adding drama and suspense to the action scenes. This, along with the great cinematography and design, gives credit to Christopher Nolan's talent as a director.

But that talent only goes so far. Along with its great aspects, "The Dark Knight" has two major problems. The first is Harvey Dent. The turn his character takes simply does not make any sense. In one scene he is sacrificing himself for the betterment of the city and standing up to criminals everywhere. In the next, he is holding a gun to a boy's head. And why is this? Because his girlfriend gets killed? It just doesn't add up. Of course it would be fine if the film were overall more fantastic and unrealistic, but Nolan makes it obvious that he is emphasizing realism. Due to this, Dent's dramatic character turn just doesn't fit. With a lot more development it may have worked, but, alas, Nolan was already pushing it with the length of the film, and I'm sure the producers wouldn't have been happy with a half hour more about how and why Dent turned bad.

The second major flaw of the film is by far its most significant and ubiquitous. It can all be summed up by the fact that such a dark, realistic film was rated PG-13. PG-13? How cold that be possible? Wasn't the Joker cutting up some people's faces and executing others at point blank range? Wasn't this a really evil man? Unfortunately, he wasn't. And this is due to the severe editing and toning down of the violence, which is felt throughout the entire film. We know the Joker is doing bad things, but we don't ever really see them. The camera cuts away when he is supposed to kill the black mob boss with his knife. The whole scene is skipped where he breaks out of his cell and, as can only be imagined, he kills all the officers guarding him. And it's not just with the Joker; it's everywhere in the movie. In the final scene, Dent is not pointing the gun at the boy's head (which I'm sure would have given the film an R rating); he just has it near the boy. If we are to believe and appreciate how dark the film is and how evil the Joker is, we need to see it! We can't be satisfied by a PG-13 depiction of this sort of violence! Indeed, the tone and character of the film are directly contradicted by its dearth of violence and terror. Consequently, the film suffers. We simply don't get a fulfillment of the darkness that the film promises. Indeed, it's severe editing not only causes it to lose a lot of character development for both the Joker and Dent, but we also don't get a truly dark, realistic superhero film. We only get three-quarters of one. 

Why does this happen? My best guess is money. I'm certain that at least part of Christopher Nolan wanted to make "The Dark Knight" as dark as its tone insinuates, but perhaps pressure from the producers or simple greed made him tone down the film to get its PG-13 rating. With such a rating, many more people could see it, and it made a lot more money. Unfortunately, however, this sacrificed its chance at true greatness and originality. We are only given part of a film, and because of this, it cannot even be seen as one of the best of the decade. In the end, I can only say one thing to Christopher Nolan: I hope it was worth it.

The Dark Knight permeates into multiple genres, nearing the brink of perfection in each category. Nolan pulls from a plethora of rich resources to construct a complex, yet engaging story. Deep emotion drives the character's every move, while the plot emits a fascinating energy that propels the viewers into each scene. The Dark Knight redefines the super-hero genre by rescaling the story of one individual into the lives of Gotham's everyday citizens, creating a multiplex of subtle themes that call for the rise of a plebeian hero. Nolan magnifies the scope of his tale by adding mortal elements of vulnerability and fear, evoking a sympathetic notion that highlights the human nature of Gotham's finest. The Dark Knight triumphs in a hero that dwells in our very own circumstance, battling a villain that caricutarizes society's capacity to harbor chaos and anarchy as a response to fear. Heath Ledger's electrifying performance as the Joker is the catalyst by which our plot unfolds, unleashing a torrent of commotion that fuels the passionate performances of the protagonists. While the film seeks to occupy the everyday familiarities, it also construes a surreal notion of capturing the most dramatic moments with little regard to the temporal continuity of the plot. The Dark Knight ultimately covers more ground with an extensive approach to montage editing, always keeping one step ahead of the audience's mind. Nolan assembles one of the finest masterpieces of recent times by maintaining a sharp edge amidst the prevalent woes of many other big-budget, blockbuster features that neglect depth and vision for mindless substitutes that lack in artistic innovation.

Just an epic super hero movie, that isn't as much of a super hero film as it is an epic crime film. I like stuff that's real, and this had more of a real feel to it. It was more revolved around real people, and it didn't have some cheesy story, or a cheesy villain. The Batman is a symbol of hope for the city of Gotham, and he helps fight the mob with the police. The first one is when he began, but this is when he has made a huge difference in the city, and when he is forced between the borderline of hero and vigilante. In the Dark Knight series he is what ever the city needs him to be. Weather it is a hero, criminal, vigilante, or just a symbol. 
How this film is the most different from the 3: In Batman Begins, and The Dark Knight Rises the villains are trying to destroy the entire city, and the people in the city all panic, and there is rioting. In this one it is Batman against one man. The Joker is trying to take away all hope for the city of Gotham, and show how crazy the city is because of Batman, and he wants to turn the city against him. Batman has to reveal his true identity, to save lives, but he knows he shouldn't because he will get arrested, and the city will be in big trouble. This one, and the Dark Knight Rises are the two that have the most conflict for the Batman. 

Now Heath Ledger is everything everybody will tell you he is. He became the Joker. He blew Jack Nicholson right out of the water. Jack Nicholson played a funny, and silly Joker. Heath Ledger plays a really scary Joker, that is creepy, and terrifying as it gets. He played the role so well, that the other cast members admitted that they forgot their lines because they thought he was so scary. All of the little details that go into his performance of the Joker, such as the facial ticks, the voice, his laugh, and creepy facial expressions were all so perfect. There are so many scenes where you are amazed by how good he is. Heath Ledger obviously had an amazing range as an actor. He played a gay cowboy in Brokeback Mountain, the son of a nasty racist man in Monsters ball, and then he comes out and plays the greatest Joker of all time by far. The makeup job they did with him was fantastic, because it didn't cover his face evenly in every area. That made him look even more frightening, and like some guy who you wouldn't even be able to speak when you say him. You can't even tell it is he, because of his acting, and his makeup. He has this genius master plan to beat the city of Gotham, and turn the city against Batman. One of my favorite lines is "Do I really look like a guy with a plan?" He actually did. Though he is an evil psychopath, he is really smart. 
I loved the scene when he blows up the hospital, and as he is walking away he never look back until the explosion stops, and he has to figure out the remote. Then when it works he runs away, and never looks back. That was really good acting on Heath Ledgers part that made the scene even more convincing. Also when he is about to say to blow up the boat, and then he asks batman "Did I ever tell you how I got these scars?" You really want him to say another story. There were many scenes like that where you want too see more. Like the scene where he says we are going to have tryouts. I wanted to see what happened in that scene. 

Aaron Eckhart I thought was the 2nd best person in the film. He played the very likeable Harvey Dent. Harvey Dent is the savior of Gotham, and has put so many criminals behind bar, and he did it without a mask. His fight against organized crime is the first successful one that was legitimate, Gotham has ever seen. He is in love with Rachel Dawes who is also Bruce Wayne's love interest. Bruce tries to steal her from Harvey, which he doesn't. Harvey does some really heroic things such as claiming he is the batman so the real batman won't have to turn himself in to save everybody from the Joker. The joker's master plan in the end made Harvey Break bad. Half of his face gets completely burnt, and he becomes two-face. Why Aaron Eckhart is good in this, is because he plays the loveable Harvey Dent who is the symbol of hope for Gotham city, and he also plays the villain Two Face. 

There are certain themes and sayings that are really awesome in this movie that are famous now. Such as "You either die a hero, or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain," and "Some men just want to watch the world burn." This movie is just like candy it's so sweet in so many areas. The action is amazing. The bat mobile is awesome, but the Bat pod is just so cool. I love the huge tires it has, and it looks so real. 

The film has a few similar scenes from the Batman where Jack Nicholson was the Joker. Jack Nicholson stood in the middle of the street saying come on and hit me, while Batman was flying at him with his plane. He flew over him because he didn't want to kill him. Heath Ledger stood there with a shotgun saying, "Come on hit me, I want you to do It." while batman was driving to him on the Bat pod. Batman drove around him, and crashed because he didn't want to hit him, just like Michael Keaton did with Jack Nicholson. Jack Nicholson fell from a tall building to his death. Heath ledger nearly fell to his death, until Batman saved him. The two films have some similar scenes like that, but the Dark Knight is better because it is much more serious. Batman is supposed to be dark, which is why this is so much better. 

The only things that I thought were bad in this film were the way the Joker escaped from the prison. Well it was actually an awesome scene, but obvious, and stupid the way he did it. They wouldn't leave a guard in the interrogation room with him. They left him in there so he could escape. Also when he is holding the knife to his neck, and asks for his phone call, they would shoot him because he left his head open. Also he wouldn't be able to talk to Harvey Dent in the hospital, because they evacuated all of them. You would think that the first thing they would do is evacuating Harvey, because he is the city's district attorney, and not just leave him in the hospital.
