The Dark Knights is a landmark film in the comic book hero film genre that has spun countless films but has never seemed so complete, so deep and so close to perfection. Christopher Nolan, who had already shown his understanding of the character of Batman by giving him and Gotham City a true representation that justified the emphasis on the pseudonym of the dark knight, returns to the scene of the crime in a second film with a better screenplay with an intriguing but never intricate screenplay that assures an engaging kind of entertainment that is rare to find. Furthermore, the strength also lies in the characters, so well defined whether it is the titular vigilante or the historical enemy The Joker portrayed in an intense and compelling way by Ledger, whose premature death took place prior to the release of the film. And while the photography stuns and the effects amaze, it is clear to see all throughout that everything in this film seems right, and everything after this film would never be the same for a genre that had been heavily commercialised since its inception.

Ver películas de un subgénero que sobresalen soberbiamente de la media como Spider-Man 2 es un placer. Llegó 2008 y salió una película de un subgénero, que logró arrasar en todos los aspectos incluso a grandes filmes que hoy en día se consideran clásicos. Y aquí está. Pues 'El caballero oscuro' ('The Dark Knight' en el original) no sólo es una gran película basada en un cómic, sino también un emocionante thriller que le da un toque que será muy, pero que muy difícil superar. No es la mejor película de la historia, ni es perfecta, ni lo pretende. Pero gracias a su sublime, bien explotada, equilibrada y desarrollada historia, sus admirables actuaciones (sobre todo la de Heath Ledger (Q.E.P.D.)) y su brillante y dinámico espectáculo visual y sonoro hacen que se acerque mucho a ese nivel. Es una nueva y reflexiva aportación al género, mezclando sabiamente lo viejo con lo nuevo, cogiendo elementos del cómic y llevándolos a un mundo, si bien no completamente realista, muy creíble y convincente. En resumen: Nolan ha creado una película redonda e inolvidable; la mejor película del subgénero, una de las mejores de las que he visto, y desde luego, mi favorita.

The second installment of Nolan's epic series, The Dark Knight also happens to be my personal favorite. While not as dark as the first (in both cinematography and story), it is certainly more chaotic. The theme of the movie is order vs chaos, first laid out as Batman vs vigilantes, then Harvey Dent vs Batman, Batman vs Joker, etc. As the movie tactfully lays out, they aren't necessarily opposites, but sometimes one in the same, and sometimes creating each other. Heath Ledger is superior to the Jack Nicholson version of the Joker, and fits this trilogy perfectly, being more realistic and less cartoonish (though how realistic is a guy wearing clown makeup), sometimes hilarious, occasionally terrifying, and always certifiably creepy. The action sequences are better than the first installment for sure. Harvey Dent is played decently enough by Aaron Eckhart, and Gary Oldman, Morgan Freeman and Michael Caine all continue to give great performances. The only downgrade here is Rachel, played by the talentless Maggie Gyllenhaal, but it can be forgiven as Katie Holmes didn't set a high standard. Sometimes it seems the movie is too long, but it's a well-written story with multiple surprises that make it unpredictable and very enjoyable. I think it's the best superhero movie of all-time, and an absolute must-see.

The picture-perfect Batman movie; dark and gritty and tragic but ultimately optimistic and meaningful, with an armful of colorful characters tossed in for seasoning. Of course, it's impossible to discuss the film without first touching on Heath Ledger, whose magnificent turn as the Joker unconscionably steals the show from the very moment he appears on the screen. Magical moments, memories and faces routinely come and go on the silver screen, but a role this iconic only comes around once or twice a generation, and the power of his appearance has been amplified over the years. Ledger deserves every bit of the credit he reaped for the part, even if his untimely demise may have heightened the hype to superhuman levels. The things his character gets to do, say, and imply are downright remarkable, and really elevate this from a very good superhero movie into a brilliant social commentary that just so happens to revolve around a man with a cape, cowl and vast personal armory. As in Batman Begins, the supporting cast is heavily peppered with brilliant performances from Hollywood's heavy-hitters, with particularly excellent showings from Michael Caine, Morgan Freeman and Aaron Eckhart, and once again Christian Bale masterfully inhabits the dual roles of Bruce Wayne and Batman. It's a great action movie, detective story, political thriller, superhero flick and moral tragedy, never feels half as long as its 152 minute run time lets on, and sticks the landing in every single important scene. One for the ages.

Reprise the stellar cast and sincere performances, but this time Christian Bale is more comfortable and powerful in his role as Bruce Wayne, and more believable as Batman.  Aaron Eckhart is a very believable Harvey Dent, and his transition to Two-Face, while somewhat abrupt, lends itself to feelings of despair.  The only blow to the cast is the absence of Katie Holmes, who played a more serious and down to earth Dawes; Maggie Gyllenhaal's performance is adequate on it's own, but falters slightly when measured against her predecessor.  However, it's Heath Ledger's performance as the Joker that leaves the biggest impression; every tone, every facial expression, every gesture is compelling.  Heath Ledger does a fantastic job of portraying the Joker as an "agent of chaos," a madman interested only in confusion and destruction, Batman's penultimate nemesis.  Ledger's performance leads the audience to almost feel an understanding of such a character, in concert with an impression of believable unpredictability.  Another powerful tool is employed when the film actually incorporates complaints about the first film as improvement/evolution of the Batman, his arsenal and his _modus operandi_ that occur in this film.  Finally the story, with its span and complexity, driven by its characters and ambiance - just as was Batman Begins, which was a journey of self-discovery on which the audience accompanied Bruce Wayne - feels like a journey into the heart of Gotham.  This film is quite probably the best super-hero motion picture to date.

It's worth noting that, four years after its success made the big summer superhero movie less the pleasant resurgence it was after Batman Begins and more of an annual (and oftentimes grudging) obligation, The Dark Knight still stands as the apex of the genre. Part of that, of course, is just because it's a terrifically entertaining movie. Like most Hollywood sequels, it ups the spectacle of its predecessor; but unlike most, it does so while also telling a more ambitious and rewarding story. And though by the third act one definitely feels the strain of the two-and-a-half runtime, those 150 minutes are astonishingly some of the tensest I've ever experienced: it's telling that two of the most frequently recurring motifs in Hans Zimmer's score sound like a ticking clock and a siren. Most of that intensity can be traced directly to Heath Ledger's performance as the Joker, which is riveting not because of his untimely death (if that was the case, wouldn't we be canonizing The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus?), but because he's just that good: he takes the madcap anarchism of Jack Nicholson's 1989 performance and injects it with a barely restrained, and genuinely terrifying, sense of menace. After a first film in which, despite entertaining turns by Liam Neeson as Ra's al Ghul and Cillian Murphy as the Scarecrow, Batman still ended up carrying the movie, it's kind of nice to see the villain steal the show again as nature intended.

For me, though, The Dark Knight's real achievement is in the liberties it takes with the superhero genre--or, for that matter, the mainstream action movie in general. I can't recall any other blockbuster from at least the last 30 years where the hero's victory is as pyrrhic and ambiguous as Batman's is in this film. Indeed, like a great revisionist Western, The Dark Knight isn't really about "heroism" in the unproblematic sense at all, but rather about the place of violence in contemporary society, the tensions between law and disorder, and the ethics of societal control in the face of chaos. How many other mainstream American movies, much less summer popcorn flicks, so thoroughly call into question the motives and justification of their protagonists, asking us not only to parse the differences between "good" and "evil" but to acknowledge their complex interrelatedness, the culpability the former can have in creating the latter? These questions, of course, don't always have ideologically convenient answers. Critics on both sides of the political spectrum have interpreted The Dark Knight as an apologia for the War on Terror and the police-state anxieties of the Patriot Act; I don't agree with those particular conclusions, but I can see where they're coming from (just like I can see that, on one level, Batman can look like a right-wing plutocrat who solves problems alternatively with his money and his fists and thinks he is above the law). But the fact that we are able to come to those conclusions, even if they're unappealing to us, is part of the point of moral ambiguity; and I think a film like this, one that challenges and unsettles us even as it entertains, is something to be celebrated, and one of the best arguments for commercial cinema I can think of.

Christopher Nolan, tenho que dizer, é sem dúvidas um dos melhores diretores da atualidade. Responsável por grandes trabalhos como "Insônia" e "A Origem", ele não apenas faz filmes: eles os transforma em obras de arte, exigindo a atenção de quem assiste para que a trama possa ser compreendida e apreciada.
"Batman - O Cavaleiro das Trevas" é um obra absolutamente sensacional em vários sentidos da palavra. Tem uma estupenda fotografia gótica de Gotham City, com o predomínio de cores escuras, que acaba dando um tom muito sombrio ao filme. Uma história super envolvente e de tirar o fôlego, repleta de charadas, diálogos inteligentes (como todo filme do Nolan). Sequências de ação absurdamente bem filmadas, que te fazem ficar na ponta da cadeira de tanta tensão e envolvimento. E o melhor de tudo: tem um elenco fenomenal! Christian Bale como o Batman, faz todos os atores que interpretaram o herói no passado parecerem palhaços. Katie Holmes como a Rachel Dawes, em uma super carismática interpretação. Grandes atores como Gary Oldman, Morgan Freeman e Michael Caine dando um show de bola. E, aí é que está, a melhor atuação do filme que é sem dúvidas a do Heath Ledger (o Coringa) que fez, faz e ainda fará o público que assistir o filme se espantar com a qualidade de sua interpretação antológica e inesquecível, superior sem dúvidas a de Jack Nicholson (o Coringa anterior do filme do Tim Burton).
Eu tenho um lema que vou sempre levar pela a minha vida: "Nunca crie expectativas para um filme!". Mas, alterando o meu lema, eu poderia muito bem dizer: "Nunca crie expectativas para um filme... A não ser que ele seja do Christopher Nolan".

First off, I'm gonna go ahead and devote a VERY large chunk of this to the stellar and groundbreaking performance of Heath Ledger as The Joker. He was awesome! He made Joker almost human. He wasn't just some crazy guy dressed up like some clown. In fact, his appearance wasn't even referenced to as clownlike apart from his henchmen. To me, Heath made Joker a man who was  ,in some sort of insane way, very down to Earth and realistic. He's got a method behind the Joker's madness. The Joker was right in his own twisted way. He knew what the world was. He saw the Earth for the monster it was and unfortunately, he let that monster consume and spit him out as a monster himself. Heath Ledger forever redefined this longtime enemy of the Batman and I pity the man who has to try to top Heath's performance. In his final film, Heath Ledger gave us arguably one of his greatest, if not the greatest, performance of his career. His wicked performance even won him an Oscar for Best Actor in a Supporting Role. Soo...Heath Ledger, we thank you for gracing us all with a beautiful portrayal. 

NOW...onto the movie itself. Okay, it topped Batman Begins on multiple levels such as acting, action, storyline and realism. I've seen TDKR and I still prefer this one. It was just so much better. Heath Ledger as The Joker was a much more fun character than Tom Hardy as Bane, obviously and he was planning to take Batman's city and turn it against him right in Batman's face whereas Bane just simply wanted to destroy Gotham. Christian Bale as Batman? ...Eh. He was better than George Clooney. Even though I prefer Michael Keaton, I've got to give my condolences to Bale. He really did work into this film. He was a great Bruce Wayne and an ok Batman. If anything, the problem I have with Bale is that hacking noise he makes as Batman. Ugh...he's everything Batman should and would be but do they have to make it sound like he swallowed an entire stick of bread? In some scenes in TDKR, he growls so much you can't understand what he's saying. That is my real only gripe about Bale as the Bat. 

This movie gave us a harsh and grim look at what society could do during a war between a vigilante and a terrorist. How far a world without rules could go to survive and how quickly one man can turn everything upside down. It also gives us a glimpse of how quickly heroes like Harvey Dent can fall vulnerable and become corrupted. Christopher Nolan mixed these elements all in and he gave us arguably the greatest Superhero film in a long time. Be sure to check it out and be amazed.

The best superhero movie of all time. One of the most intense crime dramas and top action film ever. But above all, The Dark Knight is one of the greatest experiences in cinema history. After rebooting the Batman franchise in 2005 with the successful Batman Begins, Christopher Nolan returns with a bang. Alongside Nolan stands a brilliant cast  of Christian Bale, Michael Caine, Gary Oldman, the late Heath Ledger and others, who all contribute in bringing the film to life. The story is near flawless, keeping you on the edge of your seat and leaving you excited, frightened, hopefull, then hopeless. Hans Zimmer and James Newton Howard's music speeds up the movie in scenes of action and thrill but also slows down the film in moments of fear and emotion. I was blown away when I first saw The Dark Knight, and between 2008 and now, I have viewed it many times. If you have yet to see this masterpiece, then I hope my review has convinced you to. As the Joker said, "All it takes is a little push."

Only one other time have I sat and watched a film and been mesmerized by its perfection. Every scene, every character, every line of dialogue.... perfect. Nolan went alot darker with his sequel and the result was a superhero film which could have been a gangster film. For Heath Ledger to receive an oscar for a performance in a superhero reboot then need I say more about how perfect is was. The main trait of this movie which I felt the Dark Knight Rise's lacked was the various scenes of Bruce Wayne talking to Harvey Dent, Commissioner Gordon....  and it must have made the dialogue just fall on to the page as Jonathan Nolan was writing it. It created the perfect situations for subtext and probably made the actors job on this film a dream too. The film revolves around Bruce Wayne (the Dark Knight) attempting to pass the mantle to Harvey Dent (the White Knight) in order to spend the rest of his days with the love of his Life Rachel Dawes. But like all good superhero movie's it never turns out the way they want it. It leads to an explosive finally where we learn that even the incorruptible can eventually be broken and leave's Bruce Wayne no alternative then to stick to his guns and take the wrap. The film is very clever by hardly ever using the word hero... he's a silent guardian and this perfectionism doesn't stop there... its in every line of dialogue, every costume.... every stunt. The opening scene alone will leave you satisfied as it's a mini short film within a feature. My favourite line of the whole movie is "this is what happens when an immovable object meets an unstoppable force" and for me this is the sole reason Dark Knight Rise's fell short. Christopher Nolan's Batman and Joker are the perfect arch rivals. It's in my top ten and IMDB's top ten films of all time. Watch it and I doubt you won't feel the same way.
